Some games you play for the fun. Some games you play for the challenge. Others you play for the story, the personality, and sometimes the beauty, or maybe the music. Cave Story is a game where every one of these things keeps me going, and I don't think I can say that about any other.

This game is beautiful, fun, challenging, and one of those true works of art that make me really happy. This famous indie game is definitely worth it no matter what kind of gamer you are.

reviewText:
It’s not easy to even start talking about Cave Story without starting to throw out such adjectives like “modern classic” or “cult underground hit”. But there, you have it, I just wrote it and I won’t take it back. This game preceded the current state of indie scene by a few years, back when it was released as freeware title in 2004. In a few years it was improved and expanded to various platforms with more content and refined graphics. It even was remade in 3D and published for 3DS, though that particular version lacks to provide definitive Cave Story experience. But in the beginning it was made by a single developer on his free time. His name was Daisuke Amaya. The fact that this guy is japanese (not that you couldn’t tell it by his name) explains a lot. Like, for starters, game’s setting and plot.
Taking place inside giant floating island inhabited by giant sentient rabbit-like creatures called Mimigas this story is both absurd and complex. Starting out very light-hearted game is filled with tremendous amount of jokes. While the story develops, it tends to grow deeper and more brutal than you might think it’ll turn out. Like many metroidvanias do, game prefers not to present you with the world details and backstory, but rather let you explore it by yourself. A vague prologue, which will leave player clueless transits to waking up in a cave. A silent protagonist suffering from memory loss, as cliché as it is, works as perfect instrument here. You wake up, you find a gun, you begin your journey. Your mission, your ultimate goal is covered with the mystery. And discovering it can’t be done separately with finding an answer to an even more important question “What the hell is going on here?” But searching it won’t be similar to aimless wandering around. Cave Story keeps a very good pace, presenting you with new goals and providing directions to them on the go. It isn’t large glowing marker on the map though, but rather clevel organization of levels and progression of the story. Exploring and finding hidden secrets is present in the game, but size of the areas isn’t overwhelming and new levels are introduced one by one. There is though few very unobvious decisions that change the outcome of the game drastically. So if you want to achieve the best ending prepare to keep a keen eye for details or rather even look for some guides.
From the perspective of game mechanics it’s the usual run-jump-shoot trio, but with a few twists. One of them is leveling system. Killed enemies drop yellow triangles, which fill the progression bar of currently equipped weapon. Fully filled bar increases weapon level, up to maximum third, but taking damage drops the bar back down, so prepare for some micromanagement. Weapons have different shooting patterns. There is Polar Star which fires plain bullets, then there’s Fireball which produces bouncing deadly balls of fire. Then there’s Spur which has chargeable beam; the longer you charge it, the more powerful the resulting shot will be. Plenty of choices results in very different strategies player can use. Though you’ll tend to have favourites among your arsenal, keeping them all leveled up and ready will be invaluable. To make things even more complex some of the weapons can be traded off in exchange providing you with other guns which have different qualities. This changes are sometimes mutually exclusive and not always reversible, so don’t answer yes every time some friendly NPC offers you something, that’s my advice here. Unlike your main interaction tools your character doesn’t really level up, with the exception of few valuable health upgrades. Not very hard if you keep the default path game is horribly ruthless when it comes to that last levels of the “best ending” branch. How does it sound for you: beating a few sequential levels swarming with enemies and two bosses? If you fail, you start again from the very beginning. That’s very different from the main path, where you’ll find save points after every major event. But then again, it’s for those who want to fully beat the game. For those who are trained and prepared there are even special timer for that last sequence, beating last boss before time runs out will unlock one of the few special music tracks in main menu. The themes depend on how fast you complete it, a new one for each minute saved. And that happens only if you found special secret item, but I guess that won’t be a problem for those who are that deep in the game.
Cave Story stands on the shoulders of giants, combining elements from both Metroid and Mega Man. But it goes further than just simple copying of old classics. It is polished and compelling and its influence knows no merits; nearly every modern 2D-metroidvania has taken some lessons from here. A must-have experience if you call yourself a lover of modern indie-games.

reviewText:
So; a game released initially for free years ago is now avaliable for almost 20 dollars.
Is it worth it...?

...depends!

Cave Story+ is the most definitive version of the game ever released in my own opinion, trumping other releases on consoles, and the original in terms of raw content. Cave Story+ boasts extra gameplay modes, stages, the ability to switch between the original and new graphics and music (And the WiiWare exclusive music too!), difficulty modes, little easter eggs, and a few things I probably don't have memorized sprinkled on top of an already amazing game.

The problem I have recommending it to most people is that the original Cave Story is still out for no money whatsoever and includes the entire length of the main game. If you're not comfortable whatsoever about paying money for Cave Story+, you can still get the original for exactly 0 dollars and decide whether or not the extra content will be worth your time based on how much you enjoyed it.

I'll be honest in saying that paying that amount of money for Cave Story+ feels like a bit of a rip once you've played the original and know its plot inside and out, but if you're like me and you really enjoy playing the game whenever you can, you won't really mind it. In reality, I own about six different copies of Cave Story between Nintendo systems and my computer, so you can tell I'm a bit of a nut about this game. There's something about the atmosphere, characters, and gameplay that just make it beyond awesome and a blast to play every single time.


In any case, I will always recommend you play the original first. It's free, and it's a timeless classic made by one man. You will enjoy it. If you come to love it just as much as I do and you need more, definitely grab Cave Story+ when you can (though maybe on a sale!)

reviewText:
About a year ago, I actually recommended Cave Story+ to my friends. It was probably the longest recommendation I ever made. What I basically said was that it was the best version of Cave Story that you can get, with everything being perfect aside from one issue, which I will get to later. The reason why I've deleted the recommendation and made a new review is because I really don't think I did the game justice. I would go as far as to say that Cave Story is in my top 3 favourite games of all time, and considering my other two favourite games are exclusive to consoles, and that I believe this is the best version of Cave Story there is, I might go as far as to say this is my favourite Steam game of all time.

If you want an explanation of what Cave Story is, I’ll tell you as much as I can without either spoiling your or me getting bored. You begin playing as a mute… “boy” that is suffering from amnesia, and just woken up in a cave. From there, you find a variety of different characters, amongst them is a race of rabbit-puppy creatures called Mimiga’s. They are suffering because there is a man known as “the doctor” who has come to their Mimiga Village to kidnap them individually. I won’t go into any more detail because, as the title implies, the “Story” in Cave Story, and finding out who this “Mysterious amnesia boy” actually is, is a huge strongpoint of the game.

This game isn’t just full with amazing storytelling either, the gameplay is amazingly fun too. It’s a Metroidvania that doesn’t focus on backtracking… most of the time (IM LOOKING AT YOU, GRASSTOWN!). Your main weapons are the guns you find along your journey, and how they work is actually really interesting and fun. The way that I would explain it is that it’s kinda like an RPG, as your guns can gain experience to make them more powerful. This may sound broken, but your guns can’t actually go any higher then level 3, and if you get hit while your gun has high experience, you will actually start to lose some of those points. It may sound annoying and tedious, but it’s actually extremely fun, and it’s a great punishment for getting hit a couple of times.

Now that we got how everything in Cave Story works, I want to go into comparing Cave Story+ to the original Cave Story. Most of Cave Story’s fame not only comes from that it’s an amazing game, but the whole of the original was made by one person, and he actually released the game for FREE (This may not sound like much now, but remember this game originally came out in 2004). Now you may be thinking “But if the original version is free, why should I bother with this one?” That’s an easy answer, BECAUSE IT’S BETTER IN EVERY WAY. The original game was very 8-bit inspired, something that’s usually looked down on indie developers nowadays, but back then people would say that it’s a great call-back to old NES games. Cave Story+ turns the original 8-bit game into more of a 16-bit feel, and it actually makes the game better for it. Of course, you can change the options so that it’s like the original, but the new version is so much better. That’s not the only thing they added either, there are new gameplay modes that add new levels that you can play, or a boss rush mode, and many, many more.

The only complaint I have for this game is its controls. Believe it or not, even though the game originally came out for PC, the CONSOLE CONTROLS are actually better! If you don’t like using the arrow keys to move, or pressing “up” to jump (which sickens me to think about), you’ll have to change the controls for a bit so that they match up with how you play.

So please, PLEASE buy Cave Story+. If you’re really not sure, you can download the free version on the Cave Story website (you will have to add the English attachment to play it in English though), but buying the one on steam is so much better. I’ve spent way too long making this review, but trust me, it’s worth it. This game is amazing.

(Also excuse me for my horrible grammar in this review)

reviewText:
You wanna know what makes this game awesome? Allow me to explain.

Pros
• Easy controls, quick pickup and play and convenience.
• Metroid-like gameplay style with Kirby-esque pudding mix.
• Simple, elegant storyline that gives just enough purpose to wreck shtuff.
• Catchy music.
• Awesome controller support.

Cons:
• Not enough people know about this game.
• Not enough people still like pixel-art style platformers.
• You don't own this game yet (unless you like reading reviews after purchase).

Notes:
• I played from beginning to end as part of my Indie adventure. It's very fun and worth at least the first playthrough.
• Don't use the Life Pot. You'll know when you actually need it, trust me.

reviewText:
When it comes to a straight honest opinion of Cave Story, I would consider this game the pinnacle of indie games; everything that makes them fantastic and sticks out from the crowd. I go as far to say how easily they can surpass major blockbuster games both in sales, ratings and of course, the fans that cherish it so.

I will not spoil much about this game, other than the fact it plays out as a retro sidescrolling, platform-adventure game; very reminiscent of the early-mid 90's and the plethora of game titles of that time, such as Mega Man and Super Metroid for the SNES. To top this all off the graphics, programming, story and overall direction was made by one man.

To the newcomers of Cave Story, take my advice and play this game slowly at a steady pace and try not to ask for any outside help, as you may experience the intriguing creativity of this game for yourself and the other first timers who have stumbled upon this game for the first time also. I've only played a couple of hours of this, and countless hours on the freeware version so trust me when I say this wonderful indie, platform-adventure game is far beyond perfection.

reviewText:
I love cave story. I love the story, I love the art style, I love that you can save curly, I love that you can play as curly, I love the dogs, I love the weapons, I love the enemies, I love the challenge of hard mode, I love the endings, I love the characters, I love the level design, I LOVE IT ALL.

Why do I love it all? because it's well paced, the game feels as though its a 100% done project, probably because it is. All the kinks are out, the story isn't flawed nothing is broken about the game, and it gives me a good reminder of hard games, and platformers being fun in general. I'm not a huge fan of platformers right now because they all seem so short and incomplete. Cave Story, is NOT that.

So buy the game, play it yourself or if you don't have money, the old flash of the game is out there somewhere, go find it. you'll just have 8bit graphics. it's not a real downgrade.

As for Cave Story + though, and why you should get it:
Uhh... graphics... challenges... stuff..... sounds.... music?
It's just what it sounds like... cave story +, it's just a refreshed version of the older game, so yeah I would recommend it to anyone and everyone.

Not much else to say.... the game is worth it all though.

Standard Game RatingStory: 10/10 (Complete, involves a few places where the player can choose a better path than the standard story)
Gameplay: 10/10 (You can re-bind the controls now, and use a controller if thats your thing... and the whole game has solid gameplay, and it's as balanced as a singleplayer RPG platformer gets. Ultimate weapons arent way too OP, and rockets aren't even a thing in hard mode. so get good.)
Presentation: 10/10 (Just... look at it, like take a few seconds, scroll up to the pictures and video, and look. THE GAME LOOKS GREAT!)
Soundtrack: 10/10 (The original soundtrack is still an option in the + version and the redone soundtrack is good also. Just... wow, it's on target the soundtrack is great, it's one of the few that I will listen to while playing other games.)
Replayability: 10/10 (I enjoyed speedrunning the game, and playing it on hard. you can't get bored of this thing quic, I can promise that. Also the game is 100% modable, with the right tools. Currently however there is not much of a modding community, either that r I just think we're allowed to change the files when in fact we aren't... if not... sorry.)

reviewText:
Cave Story is a great game, there's no doubt about that. It is worth playing all the way through and working towards the ending of your choice. There is great depth in the story and the player has control over the length of exploration to some extent. The characters are somewhat memorable and the story is compelling enough to keep you engaged through a playthrough.

While the story was great, what kept me fully engaged in the experience was the gameplay and the way it functions. The health system and its link to the weapon system was very satisfying and rewarding. The character movement via jumping and the jetpack was refreshing and very satisfyingly fluent.

That being said, I found it to be a little short for my liking and I struggled with certain areas while I found others far too easy, but there was nothing that overshadowed the positives of the strong narrative and the satisfying gameplay mechanics.

Overall it is a must-own title (though I would wait for a sale as it is a bit overpriced imo).

reviewText:
Cave Story is my all-time favourite game. I played it for my first time back in 2006, and it's charming story and enjoyably difficult gameplay have stuck with me to this day.

However, I cannot in good conscience recommend you spend money on Cave Story+. Cave Story was and still is a freeware game developed solely by a fellow named Pixel. A quick Google search will lead to the official tribute site where you can freely download the original Cave Story. The additions which the publisher Nicalis included in Cave Story+ are not noteworthy, and in some aspects actually detract from the original game. For example, the new visual style is quite ugly in comparison to the original, and Nicalis' altered dialogue negatively affects the impact that certain characters will have on you

I would recommend you avoid this Steam release and play the original freeware version instead. As I said, this game is fantastic, but you should enjoy it as its creator Pixel intended it to be enjoyed: as a freeware game.

reviewText:
One of the best games ever made... No questions asked. This is more than a game: it is the reason why we have games such as Super Meat Boy, To The Moon, The Binding of Isaac and many more great indie games. This game alone created the indie gaming market. If this game didn't exist: the industry would be so much different.

The first thing that you will notice about Cave Story is the retro-like style with the fantastic 8 bit like visuals and music (it is more refined than that as the game looks better than an NES game). Speaking of which, the soundtrack in this game is simply beautiful. So many tracks are flowing with emotion such as Moonsong and Geothermal, to name two. These are some of the best songs I have ever heard: I am not even joking. And most importantly, the gameplay is very good and refined.

In its heart, Cave Story is an amazing platformer shooter action game with a great story. And, the story is just fantastic. You play as a robot who wakes up in a cave. He cannot remember anything, so he finds a pistol and discovers a place called Mimiga Village. In here, he discovers the war that the cute rabbit-dog like creatures are going through currently; and you have to help.

I don't want to spoil anything, but let's just say the story gets REALLY good as it hits the narrative hook. The story, the visuals, the gameplay and the music is the reason why you will come back for more Cave Story. In fact, I am on my third playthrough at the moment! With multiple endings, difficulties and another mode, Cave Story is worth all of the money in the world. What is even better than a cheap $10 price point? The original game is free... That is right: the game is actually freeware and can be downloaded from cavestory.org. Cave Story+ brings more things to the table, but the game is worth paying for.

Trust me and all of the other die-hard Cave Story fans.... Get the game now. It is just unethical to not try the original freeware game that has changed the gaming industry forever.

reviewText:
This game is the Dark Horse of it's kind. If you have enough money in your wallet, you should totally buy it- if you like a challenge, or just want something to play in your spare time. I was expecting some short, sweet puzzle... and that's not what you get. This game is frustrating, The enemies are unforgiving. You're on your toes all the time. Your actions have consequences, and the ending can change varying on your actions, and I like that, it gives you some form of personal objective throughout the experience. I'm on the verge of completing this game after restarting a couple times just to get the best ending (I know that's a bit tedious but I know I'd regret it if I didn't).
The plot just grows thicker after every task you complete, you could insert a pretty neat pop culture reference here but I can't seem to pin point one that fits it to a T.
There's so much more to this game than I can find the words to explain correctly, In fact, I think 'Game' is a pretty undermining word for this masterpiece. Pixel has injected gold into this.
Even the tracks are GOAT, they never get boring.
This game has triumphed my heart.

reviewText:
Cave Story+ is an overall good metroidvania experience with some memorable tunes and a bit of humor. It provides around 6 hours of fun for a single playthrough and some light frustration. I tried using a guide to access the best ending, but uh… more on that later. I should also note that this version of Cave Story looks much better than the original, but you can choose to play with the classic graphics and music should you want to check those out.

GameplayYou will do plenty of jumping, shooting, and exploring. Every weapon you have at your disposal will have 3 levels with each one acting or performing differently. The Machine Gun, for example, will plink away rapidly at enemies at level 1, but at level 3, you can fire downwards to hover or gain height. The Missile Launcher will fire a single missile at level 1 and 3 missiles at level 3. Be aware that weapons can lose their experience whenever you take damage. This encourages learning how to avoid or destroy enemies effectively while collecting the valuable experience to keep you powerful. I definitely did everything I could to make sure my weapons would stay at max level in preparation for the many boss fights that the game has to offer.

The platforming aspect remains fairly simple until you acquire either the Machine Gun or a booster which opens up directional air dashing (up down left right). Before acquiring those kind of items, you’ll mostly be using your basic jump to navigate the levels and the obstacles within. Some areas of the game can require very precise jumps and movement. Failing to play well can result in instant death depending on the area. Some areas have instant death spikes, instant death crushing, or falling to your death. It’s very unpleasant to run into one of those deaths and having to go through the section again from the last save point used. Keep in mind, there are no checkpoints.

Exploration yields different benefits as you can collect health power-ups, missile launcher max ammo upgrades, find side-quests, and locate hidden items. The map is fully revealed with only hidden areas not being completely obvious.
Now I’ll bring up my issue with the best ending route. It results in one of the last areas of the normal game having a huge difficulty spike, especially for someone like me that hates instant death. It changes the area to have more spikes/obstacles and all weapons will be reset to level 1. I was able to get through eventually, but that did require more than a handful of attempts. Then you’ll need to take on an additional and very difficult dungeon that resets your weapon levels again which was completely beyond me. So if you’re around my skill level, you’d better be content with getting the good/bad endings and watching the best ending on Youtube.

Story and Other StuffThe story is simple, sad, and peppered with some odd, funny moments. The game starts you off with amnesia. From that point on, you’ll meet weird people, find weird items, discover what the heck is going on with all the bunny people (Mimigas), and unlock achievements that like to make the jokes. To know the full story, the best ending route needs to be pursued/watched since there are some important plot points and some surprises.

There are two additional modes. ?????’s Story lets you play as another character through the same game, but with additional dialog (the default protagonist is silent). You do have to find a hidden item to unlock that mode. The second one provides different challenges with different weapons. They are timed and feel like obstacle courses. I only did one. I didn’t care much for it.
-
That’s it. I’ve nothing more to say. Don’t touch the big spikes. Don’t ever touch them.

reviewText:
Overall, Cave Story was a really great game. I would defenitely reccommend this to anyone who wants a fun and challenging game to play.

Pros:
* Fluid controls
* Multiple weapons to use from a swords to bubble guns
* Weapons can level up as you kill enemies
* A pretty good story
* Multiple Endings
* Difficulty options
* Amazing soundtrack
* Great retro graphics
* Can choose between original freeware graphics and updated 16bit graphics
* Can also change between the original's 8bit music and a remastered soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky (There's also the Wiiware soundtrack if you want to torture yourself)

While the game has quite a few pros, there were a few issues I had with Cave Story.

Cons:
* Characters felt a little bland
* Getting hit can cause weapons to level down which becomes very frustrating in the later half of the game
* There are quite a few cheap deaths and injuries throughout the game
* The game tries to have sad moments, but since the characters are a bit flat and the game is quite short, I felt as though I couldn't get invested enough to feel sad for the most part
* The requirements for getting the true ending are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and there is a huge difficulty spike in order to achieve it

Overall though, I still reccommend this game to anyone who is looking for a good metroidvania styled game.

reviewText:
Cave Story...

...(aka Doukutsu Monogatari) was released on the 20th December of 2004 as a freeware game in japan, got translated by Aeon Genesis and got popular on the internet. Cave Story+ is the remake of it. It's a 8bit styled vertical platformer-shooter with nice graphics, a well done soundtrack and a great, creative story. You, a robot called Quote, awoke in a dark cave without any memories. So the only thing you can do for now is to go to the Mimiga Vilage and see whats happening there. You will find out that a evil doctor is planning to kidnap all of those rabit-like creatures and your new mission is to save those creatures and save the world.

Positive:
- Well written story
- Solid and responsible controlls
- Nice creative gameplay elements inspired from the 8bit NES classics
- New Graphics and Soundtracks
- 5 Challenges added
- New dungeon Wind Fortres" added
- Archivmentsystem added

Negative:
- Broken archivementsystem: "Curse Broken"
date:
the archivement after getting the best ending won't unlock so it is not possible to get that game 100% + Archivements won't unlock on japanese.
- Broken Replay Function in challenges: Sometimes replays won't play correctly. It happend several times to me and i'm upset about that because i've beaten Wind Fortress within 2 minutes and Sanctuary within 6 minutes and guess what? I cant see what i've done there. That sucks.
- Game closes after finishing a challenge. Thats minor but annoying. The Wii version haven't done something like that.
- English Nicalis translation. The Aeon Genesis translation looks and sounds way better than that one by Nicalis. Fortunite
recommended:
someone ported the AG translation to Cave Story+ in the Comunity guides but be aware that most of the archivements won't unlock with that translation.

Since there is a freeware version of this game here are a few things that aren't present in the freeware version:
- Difficulties:
- Easy: Player takes half damage.
(- Original: The name it self says that allready)
- Hard: Brutally challenging. You only have 3HP most of the game.
- Curly Mode (The same as the original story but you play as Curly Brace instead of Quote)
- 5 Challenges (3 of them with brutal timebased Rankings from C to S):
- New (awesome) Graphics
- New Soundtrack (some kind of softer 8bit soundtrack. Original sounds better in my opinion)
- Remastred Soundtrack (sounds like a techno mix. pretty awesome)
- New dungeon "Wind Fortres" (avaiable via challanges)
- Archivementsystem

Conclusion: It is a great remake of the original game with some things added and a high replay value. The story is binding
hoursPlayed: the characters rememberble and the gameplay nearly flawless. I can highly recomend this game for those 8bit and retro fans. For those hwo are sceptical about the game: try freeware version first. But i wouldn't buy it for 15€ (USD whatever) because it is a little bit overpriced for these addons. i would buy it for 10€

reviewText:
Cave Story is such a great game!  Its strengths lie in the storytelling and art-style.

Storywise, character development is achieved by slowly revealing new information about the characters.  The game has a level emotional depth to its characters, which is something not often found in this genre.  Multiple branches in the story will happen based on the players actions or inaction, which will have an impact on the outcomes of the characters you meet and befriend.  This branching is done in a way that it's not always apparent when you have made a 'choice'.

This depth is why I enjoyed the game (I am not a particular platformer fan) and probably why it has a sort of cult-like status.  I find it similar to how Pixar finds success in Toy Story, which has complex emotional themes despite being a movie for children.

reviewText:
Check it out ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s you can actually review games on steam now, so here's my book report miss, my dad helped me with the really long words, i even spell checked it and


Cave Story was a freeware game made by some japanese guy in his spare time over the course of 5 years as an homage to the classic vidya he'd played as a kid, like Metroid. After being released in 2004, the game recieved a cult following and was ported to the Wii and 3DS, and also to Steam with some new features, which is the version I'm reviewing right now. You play as a dude who wakes up in a cave, convieniently afflicted with amnesia, and well you run around figuring out what that you're doing on this cave which IS ACTUALLY A FLOATING ISLAND INHABITED BY CUTE RABBIT PEOPLE AND RULED OVER BY SOME CRAZY DOCTOR GUY WHO WANTS TO BRAINWASH THEM AND GET THEM TO FIGHT WARS FOR HIM SO HE CAN TAKE OVER THE WORLD

♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥♥♥, SUDDENLY YOU'RE RUNNING DOWN THIS CORRIDOR FIGHTING ELEPHANTS WITH A BB GUN TO TRY TO HATCH SOME DRAGON EGGS AND THEN YOU'RE TELEPORTING AROUND THE ISLAND ON RESCUE MISSIONS AND ♥♥♥♥, THEN YOU GET THIS GUN THAT SHOOTS BUBBLES DONT WORRY ITS REALLY GOOD AND AHH DONT SHOOT THAT YOU'LL BLOW UP THE ISLAND NOOOO

It's really fun, yeah. And the story is decent too, look, there's these cute anthropomorphic rabbits you can talk to and stuff, I don't care what you search on paheal after you're done with this game, it's all cool, man.

But the thing that put me off the game when I tried to play it a couple of years ago is the fact that there's multiple endings. Yeah, that's okay, I do like it when you get some clear cut paragon/renegade options for a good/evil end or if there's some stupid decisions you can make that'll get other main characters killed (and, as such, you can avoid making them), that's fantastic. But in Cave Story, without spoiling too much, the 'good' ending is sort of a secret path that you can only take after you've either beaten the game once and wondered, 'huh, let's try that again but I'll do that differently and see if something else happens', or if you look up a strategy guide. There is one bit that really irked me in which the game shows you something kind of important and you have to make a DELIBERATE EFFORT to avoid investigating i-okay, I'll shut up now, but the key thing that you've got to expect with this game is that you're going to '♥♥♥♥ up' in a sense on the first playthrough, and the best ending is more of a...hidden ending. But it's great. Play through it more than once, definitely, so you can try out the different weapons and stuff.

I say this in all of my recommendations but well I really ♥♥♥♥ing dig 8bit soundtracks and this game has one of the best. Pixel (the aforementioned one japanese guy) definitely did a spot-on job of capturing the feel of OLD SCHOOL VIDEO GAME BEATZ, and if THAT'S NOT ENOUGH FOR YOU, then the Plus version comes with a couple more versions of the soundtrack; a 'New' one, which is made by Nicalis and is, honestly, ♥♥♥♥ing awful, and a 'Remastered' one which is composed by none other than Danny mother♥♥♥♥ing Baranowsky,  and if you don't know who that is then ♥♥♥♥ you, it's the Super Meat Boy, Canabalt and Binding of Isaac guy.

So play through once with the classic soundtrack and get the decent ending, and then play through it again with the remastered one and get the 'true' or whatever ending and the super secret ultra gun and stuff. It's really, really fun. (I don't know if it showed up in the sale yet but if it does, you know what to do)

reviewText: Cave Story is a great game, but I can't recommend Cave Story+. Cave Story+ adds slightly higher-resolution (but still low-resolution) graphics, new music (that's inferior to the original music in my opinion), slightly better input device support, Steam integration, and some corny holiday-specific themes. But they significantly changed the game dialog, making it less charming and emotionally impactful, and to me that outweighs the new graphics. You can still download the original Cave Story for free, and if you want to support Daisuke Amaya (the creator of Cave Story), you can donate to him directly. I wish Cave Story+ included an option to use the original English text, like it does for the original graphics and music.\n\nHowever, if you want to play with a gamepad and don't want to spend any time getting it to work, Cave Story+ is probably the better choice. (It's possible to use a gamepad with the original Cave Story, but it requires some fiddling if I remember correctly.)

reviewText:
How have I not reviewed this masterpiece yet?

Impecably precise gameplay, a magnificent OST, a plethora of alternate options for replay value, an immersive story and setting with beautifully varied environments that never grates on me, passionately constructed sprites, characters I really care about (take note every other game ever, this is how to make me give a damn about NPCs) but what really makes this game stand out as a 10/10 is my emotional response.

An errant entry in my randomized music playlist and a song from this game plays--suddenly a wave of emotions consume me in an embalming torrent. Joy, inspiration, zeal, hatred, regret, anxiety, shock, hopelessness, awe, admiration, valor, this game overwhelms me with passion.

I will never give more ♥♥♥♥s than the day after I beat this game and learned that there was an alternate ending. Suddenly, ♥♥♥♥s poured out of me from every pore, bursting in flame to fuel my journey through hell.

reviewText: Anyone who plays indie games should know what Cave Story is. One of the best action adventure games ever made. reviewText: Cave Story was (not technically, but in a way and with a story) my first PC game. I remember being on a budget and my consoles packed up 3,000 miles away. I remember hearing about this game, finding it with the aid of Google Translate and nabbing the excellent fan translation. And then I experienced the first game that made me think this is a console quality experience." It was highly polished and didn't require any fiddling to make work. It had gorgeous pixel art graphics and fantastic chip tune music. The story was a tad hard to follow but very interesting and engaging. The game dripped with atmosphere. And ... it was all dreamed up and created by one man!\n\nFlash forward. In the meantime I beat this game on PC
date: I picked up the remake with optional slightly enhanced artwork and sound and beat it on Wii. And now I pick up that same game on Steam and start playing through it once again.\n\nAnd you know what? I plan on getting the 3D remake on 3DS next! There aren't many games I don't hesitate to play through again and again and even fewer I purchase again and again. Cave Story is up there in that elite list of mine. It is surely worthy of being called a classic and it is a game every gamer who grew up in the 8 and 16 bit eras will enjoy with an odd sense of nostalgia. Those growing up with gaming right now ought to take a chance and play through Cave Story."

reviewText:
Of course the game is amazing and deserves a purchase. However, Cave Story has a huge glaring issue that you need to be warned about if you've never played.

The game is cryptic as all hell. If you do not follow an extremely specific list of minute tasks (don't talk to this person, talk to this person a second time, examine an object that doesn't appear to be examinable, make this really long jump without falling, don't follow this person until you get this item, etc) then you cannot get the best ending.

I am understandably upset, because even when using a guide, I missed one tiny little step (didn't talk to a person twice) and now the best ending is off limits on my current playthrough. I now have to start all over just because I missed one small step. This cryptic method of game development irritates me to no end and should be left as a relic of the NES era.

Putting all that aside, Cave Story is still one of the best games on Steam and you should buy it rapidly. I just wanted to prepare you for one of the big problems of the game.

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played. It gives less than subtle nods to like platformers such as Megaman and Metroid, but has a very deep story. Characters do die and many of their fates rest on you and your decisions. While this game has a cute art style and happy music, it can be a very dark game when a favorite character(s) die because of something you didn't do. This game has multiple endings that feel incredibly different ie. not Mass Effect 3. This game is a blast, but is somewhat difficult to get the best ending. If you aren't completely sold I reccomend playing a bit of the original version for free  at www.cavestory.org so you know that you will enjoy it. One of my top 10 favorite games for sure, quite possibly top 5. All in all give this game a try if you want your mind blown. Fans of old school and new school games can easily enjoy this game if they are decent at platformers. If not there is an easy mode exclusive to cave story+ which does prevent you from getting the best ending. Also, I reccomend a controller. Did I mention that this game was completed totally by one guy?

You get to sleep with a bunny-girl-thing and steal an android chick's panties. 10/10, would do it again.



....besides that incredible feature, Cave Story is a real love letter to the classic metroidvania and megaman style games, it manages to mix fast paced combat and platforming action, with robust storytelling, and a surprisingly branching story depending on your actions and choices (With 3 distinct endings, as well as alternative game modes, such as playing as the protagonist's partner, with all the appropriate dialogues changes).

reviewText:
The game is a classic, and nothing I can say will deter the millions in love since it came out in 2004. I had never played this game until 2015--I didn't get into the Metroidvania genre as a kid.

The purpose of mentioning this information is that (1) I didn't grow up with this classic, and (2) so many great games have come out, especialy within its genre, that, perhaps, my issue with the game is a problem with time. More specifically, the problem of genre saturation.

Think of games like LIMBO that were the new standard of the puzzle-platformer, then those games were done over and over, and now, going back to LIMBO, the problems with the game stand more out as it's not as special as it once was.

NES-styled games (or even Metroidvania games) are not that uncommon, nor are one-man projects--for example, Dust: An Eylsian Tale, Axiom Verge, Undertale, LISA etc.--as rare today. (I'm not saying the work has become easier. The novelty of one-man projects has come and gone.)

Cave Story will continue to be an inspiration to many indie devs, and it earns its acclaim as a great game. No mistake was made there.

However... I think some aspects, both of its gameplay and of its narrative, will stand out as time continues. And this is a review to newcomers so that you don't set too high expectations for the game. (There will be no spoilers.)

Exploring the Story
First off, this game's story is almost too serious for how stupid it sounds on paper. And so many disturbing things that happen in game are quite dark when you think about the things you don't see. I love how absurd this story gets at times, but it also never forgets when to keep a straight face.

The problem I have with this story is not what it is. My problem is how it is told, namely through exposition upon exposition, sometimes rather abruptly without any dramatic weight.

I'm not against having complex plots or reading in my games. I love CRPGs after all. But this game loses all its mystique it builds up after the first hour as the game's story becomes told through constant expositions. Motives are sometimes introduced before you can imagine your own conclusions, and sometimes characters are suddenly introduced with a full backstory and the impact has no meaning.

Not every exchange is telling you information for the sake of lore. The exchanges between Quote and Curly Brace feel heartwarming, and because I am invested in both characters the exposition doesn't come off as forced. There are also messages or notes hidden that share insight on characters, which is a great way to tell stories that feel like you made a discovery.

More often this idea is a roadblock. For example, you get a character that is suddenly vital to the game's story without any foreshadowing or even a early mention, and his backstory is told while pausing the game (randomly) on the most difficult level. So not only is the story pulled out of nowhere it also gets in the way of the gameplay.

It makes me wonder why not tell the exposition by other storytelling means like environmental design. The game has one or two moments like these, and on top of the notes/messages it feels like a reward for exploration.

But that's enough to say on the story; it's small fish compared to the gameplay problems.

Exploring the Cave
For a Metroidvania game, the game feels a little barebones in its mechanics.

You get seven weapons with different arcs and effects as you level them up from collecting triangles (and you lose the XP by being constantly hit), but manyfeel worthless except for specific cases (the Fireball especially). You also get a jetpack, but not until two-thirds of the game is finished--I don't think there's a way to collect it early because, for a Metroidvania game, it's very linear. And the only items to collect are health upgrades.

The one gamplay feature that I do like is the hidden difficulty throughout most of the game. You can swap out weapons or items to make earlier sections easier, or you can bite the bullet and earn the reward later. These aren't really obvious, and you won't know you made a bad decision until much later, which some of them tie into the bonus endings of the game. (There are really only two endings with a third one being a mid-game end. You will need a guide to know how to get the final/good ending because the game asks you to do something illogical).

I really do like this feature because it ties so well into the heroic story where you influence the ones you can save and the people you simply cannot. These choices mean something.

The overall difficulty is not a fair game. Save spots are frequent through most of the game, which you will want to save often because cutscenes will be replayed upon death without a skip option. Only the boss-rush at the end, and the final level with five bosses have one save spot.

There are no E-tank substitutes--only a one-time full-health drink--but, like Megaman, you can kill smaller enemies in the boss-fights for health, weapon XP and missles. It takes real effort to regain your health in boss-fights, which I think is fine for when you have scattered save places. I would like that to be a player option rather than mandatory with the end-game'ssudden difficulty spike.

And then you have the the last level. Symbolizing only one thing: Hell. (You will need a guide to trigger this outcome--no joke.)

Either you will break your controller or you will develop a sixth sense of a bullet-hell mess for the level. Then you have to fight five boss-forms in ONE life, and if you fail you have to start all the way from the bullet-hell level. It feels like an excuse for NES difficulty rather than an actual challenge (and it reminds me too much of Street Fighter 2010: The Final Fight).

And then you have extra challenge modes and a hard mode for enthusiasts. I might do a Curley Brace mode playthrough just for dialogue changes and for the normal ending. So, thankfully, for a short game (4 to 5 hours on a normal playthrough) there is lots of replay value for sadists.

There's Still A Great Game To Be Found
Please don't let my nitpicks convince you that this game is not worth the effort. Despite the steep difficulty curve, the game is very enjoyable and I can easily recommend it.

All I want to say is just know what to expect: Don't let nostalgia keep the faults unseen because without knowing where we err we cannot know where we need to grow.

reviewText: This is arguably the best game I've ever played. Just the feel of it ever since I first played it was just too much fun! reviewText: 7.5/10\n\nCave Story will move you. The story is beautifully ominous and rich with immersion. It is a game that can be picked up time after time and still maintain it's replayability and fun. As someone who never played the original Cave Story, this game came as a great shock to me. It reminded me of oldschool platformer games like Metroid, where you could explore, find new items, get upgrades, discover secrets, whatever you so desired. A huge amount of games that try to do that can't pull it off. They do exactly the opposite of what Cave Story does. Cave Story gives the player a sense of exploration; something that can't be crafted in many games. The player IS the main character, and everything that happens will affect the player as it did the character. What detracts from this game is the same thing that detracts from every game of this genre; things like getting stuck on the same level over and over, getting stuck, and other things of the sort. I'm not going to lower this games rating because of that drastically, purely because that is sometimes what makes the game the game that it is. Example being in Zelda; you will remember the water temple more because it was a pain in the butt to beat. Things that like make Cave Story all the more memorable, and making it a game I will think about time and time again. Great indie game that everyone should play.

reviewText:
Cave Story is a retro metroidvania: a retroidvania, if you will.  The game is played with simple moving, jumping, and shooting mechanics with an emphasis on fighting but the game also requires a fair bit of platforming.  The weapons all function very differently.  They are suited for different situations and really mix up the gameplay as do the area-specific enemies.  The boss fights in particular will always force you to deal with something new and they are great fun.
The characters are suprisingly deep and they are what really made the game memorable for me.  Their personalities are communicated very well and it's easy to become attached to many of them.  The plot setup is fairly cliché but the characters and encounters keep it engaging and the story progresses at a very good pace.
The game seems to have a pretty linear progression at first, but there are secrets to be found, several sidequests, optional weapons, and multiple endings which all make the game that much richer.
Cave Story has great gameplay, a good story, memorable characters, and to top it off, an exceptional soundtrack.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that Cave Story is one of my favorite games of all time. The game draws inspiration from the likes of Mega Man, Castlevania, Contra, and Metroid, and easily measures up to the best installments of those franchises.

Cave Story, despite it's cutesy graphics, is no hand-holding experience. From the run and gun gameplay, to the hidden secrets, to the fairly simple story, players are rewarded for paying attention. With just the right difficulty curve for the average player, Cave Story has more than it's fair share of teeth-grinding, headache-inducing punishment for the player who dares to dig a little deeper.

The cast, small as it may be, is memorable and loveable.The story, simple as it may be, is fairly heavy and emotional. Conquering the true final level, hidden behind a specific sequence of events, is one of the proudest accomplishments of my two-and-a-half decade gaming career. Cave Story, from beginning to end, is action-platforming perfection.

With it's enhanced graphics and multiple soundtracks, Cave Story+ is the best version of one of the greatest games I've ever had the pleasure of playing.

reviewText:
A beautiful remake of a fun and challenging game. If you aren't looking to spend the money, you can still find the original as freeware online. Pixel did such an amazing job with this game that I was happy to see it get a remake (though I would suggest waiting until you see it on sale either through Humble Bundle or Steam Sale.. the price tag is rather high for the length of the game).

It's got tight side-scrolling action, wonderful pixel art and soundtrack (particularly the remake), challenging obstacles, multiple endings and unlocks, and a surprising amount of replayability.

It's impressive to think that the original is a decade old and was developed by one man in his free time as freeware.

reviewText: Cave Story is one of the landmark games in the history of platformers--or in Indie development in general. Developed entirely by Daisuke Amaya (the original, anyway), Cave Story is a grand unification of so many elements within the genre that it's almost the perfect platformer. The gameplay itself is challenging and rewarding, including multiple weapon types, movement modifiers, and levels for each weapon. The characters, storyline, and world are all fully cohesive, interesting, and entirely sympathetic. The music is phenomenal. The art design is retro and charming. It's hard to find anything bad to say about this game at all--so, with that in mind, if you haven't played it, buy this upgraded version right now and treat yourself to one of the best video game experiences of all time.

reviewText:
TL;DR: For a first-time player Cave Story is a solid title that has some nice surprises and that I would highly recommend, but as someone that played the original I'm extremely disappointed with this port not improving the flow of the game after all these years.

I played the freeware version awhile back and this one is slightly more polished, and with a few things added in. When I played Cave Story the first time it was a cool little free indie title, so it's amount of depth and ideas surprised me and I was pretty forgiving with it.

That being said, the issues I had with it seem to remain unchanged. The game has 3 different endings and even some secrets. Solid replayability, right? It would be, if the pacing was better.

- Fetch quests...Every time, without fail, the fetch quests discourage me from wanting to play through Cave Story again. Even the first time I played, they seemed overly-convoluted just for the sake of artifically lengethening the game. The rocket portion isn't nearly as offensive as the bomb and dog-catching parts, but still annoying.

- Unskippable dialogue. This is unexcusable for a re-release. At least allow me to hold down a button to speed through text. Technically you can, but you have to press a button at the end of every single chunk of text, so it really defeats the point. What's worse, there's tons of dialogue in the beginning portions of the game, so it further hinders the desire to replay Cave Story.

- In typical RPG fashion, you have to interact with specific NPCs or items in a specific order to progress through the story. It feels very unintuitive and could have been handled better. Particularly with the bomb part, combined with unskippable dialogue, it really kills the pacing.

- The things you have to do to get to the real final level. The amount of unintuitive BS you have to do to access the true final area is dumb. Just the whole situation with Dr. Booster falling is infuriating. Your natural instinct is to go down and save him. Ok so he dies and gives you the booster, alright. But wait how do you actually save him? By not trying to save him....no explanation given. Even worse, it's VERY difficult to not fall down, and once you do fall down, you cannot get back up without the booster, so you'd better hope you saved just beforehand or you're screwed. Nevermind all the very specfic steps involved with saving Curly Brace...

- 1-hit KO spikes. I get it, it's a 2D game and they need ways to up the challenge, but this has always felt like lazy game design to me. Particularly here where I'm a robot designed for battle and yet somehow the slighest touch of a spike kills me evem after having all upgrades.

- Not being able to customize the weapon quick-swap rotary is extremely inconvenient. In the middle of battle I want to change my weapon without cycling through the weapons I hardly use. If I ever want to use them again, then let me just equip them.

Cave Story has a lot of cool things about it, but this mostly feels like a paid Steam port (of a free game) with slightly nicer graphics and sound, that did nothing to address some of its issues.

reviewText:
If you ask yourself, how many people did it take to make this awesome game, only 1 person made this game literally and its known as the best indie game as of now. Daisuke Amaya also known as Pixel made this game for 5 years during his free time which sounds great.
You play the role of a unknown person who wakes up in the first cave, im not joking thats what the 1st level of the game is called. You lookaround the cave and 'steal' a gun from a guy who is sleeping. You soon find yourself in a village called Mimiga Village, a race of bunnies who are kidnapped from the doctor, not the one who helps you with your body i mean the one who kills you for no reason just to possess something.
As you progress through the game you find a girl who was a human but got transformed into a mimiga ( dont worry only 2 people got turned like that, every mimiga is not a human) and asks your help to escape the island with her family. You realize you are on a giant island that was a piece of the surface (its not Earth). and that your a robot who was sent to the island to kill the mimiga but you got seperated from your partner and you forgot your name (its a stupid one but im not spoiling that much). Your job in the game is, find your partnet, save the mimiga, rescue the captured mimigas from the docter, kill the docters minions and himself and 1 more thing that affects the entire island.
This game is actually harder than it looks as you find missle upgrades, health upgrades, new guns and most importantly, what you must and musnt do. There is 3 ending in the game, bad, ok and good ending. getting the good ending is hard as you must get certain items and not pick up items.
I give this game 9 out of 10 because Daisuke Amaya really took his time to make an amazing game all by himself, the music,the gameplay and the graphics. The story gets more interesting as your progress through the game and the gameplay is equevalent to everyone well not the ending as it takes hardcore players to finish.
I forgot to mention once you beat the game, you can play as your partner and everything is switch, now the partner is looking for you but its not worth sin e its the exact same thing but with diffrent dialologue.

reviewText: Cave Story is one of the best indie games I've ever played. It's also a great example of a Metroidvania game. I tried La Mulana (which is much more complex and harder) a few weeks ago, but I found Cave Story is better than that on almost every aspect (gameplay, graphics, story & music) It must be on your library if you are a loyal Humble Indie Bundle buyer, check it out now!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The first greatly successful indie game and to a certain extent, the giant spartan kick the Indie genre needed in order to become what we have these days, Minecraft and such might be whoring the spotlight, but if you are into Indie games and Cave Story doesn't ring a bell, you've made a terrible mistake, either that or you are way too young to be on the Internet.

StoryIn a word, Outlandish, the premise is very simple, entertaining but nonetheless, well-built and nicely detailed, for a twist, at times, the happenings that unfold in this relentless underground become a quite big and bitter pill to swallow.

GameplayCastlevania Story shall intensify, if you have played Super Metroid and Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, you will be right at home here, granted you are a little more restricted in both offense and exploration space, however, optional stuff is a plenty and at times, you shall need to use thy brain to earn the loot, be it the act of finding it or getting to it.
Weapons are pretty well balanced and the Level-up system encourages the player to keep a delicate balance between balls-to-the-wall guns ablazing and tactical fire, keep your defense more relevant than wrecking everything, gravity is floaty and traction can be very icy at times, not hard to get used to though, and when you get a certain amazing item, you can be both a forced to be feared and be stylish at the same time.

WritingThe ink that writes down all the events is quite elegant, i sincerely cannot recall any kind of typo and on top, everyone remains true to their individual personalities, everything is orchestated, pretty well at that, only hick-up would be some itty-bitty happenings when aiming for the Best Ending, mainly a sudden new area and a Final Boss out of nowhere with no build up.

GraphicsPixel Art rarely does dissapoint, might be a bad sentence to start this, but my point is, do you remember what I wrote at the beginning?
I can't say much for the original art, but as for the remastered art style, it overflows with detail.
I think is not very stretchy to say this has managed to stand up to the cruel bast4rd that is time.

SoundtrackOh god, the variety is way too much for a cave troll like me.
What does float your boat? Retro or Modern-retro or Modern?
Regardless of your answer, the Soundtrack option has you covered, even with different styles and approaches, they all manage to create great tunes for ambience and just ear-candy, my personal pick is the Remastered style, but be cautious, you might have some tracks burnt into the back of your mind for the next few weeks.

DurationFor a Metroidvania style game, generally one can say is on the short side, if you are quick to getting the hang of it, you can get the Good Ending in about 5 hours, but be prepared to have your patience and staying power tested and tempered if you decide to find and get the Best Ending (Difficulty walls are a beautiful thing, let me tell you).
However if you are like me (Don't do that, you're taking the wrong path) and decide to 100% this game's Achievements, oh boy, you are in a cup of lemon juice over a dry open cut.
I think its accurate to say some of these are among things that only those very dedicated people do (Looking right at you, Unstoppable and Hell under 3 mins achievements!!), not to mention one of these Achievements is bugged and will not unlock unless you use a Program, Yeah yeah, call me cheater, but i did fulfill the requirement for the Achievement rightfully, so i just claimed what is mine!
(Inb4 anyone asks, the program is here[gib.me], in case you ARE a Achievement Hunter like me and you want to get that Bugged Achievement (It's name is Curse Broken, by the way!~)
(PD: I know some people will abuse it to get EZ Achievements, but mommy ain't gonna save ya from the Ban that awaits for U!)

tl;drWhy are you still reading this? Wasn't the intro text clear enough? This is one of the finest Metroidvania Indie games in the scene out there, initially made by one guy, this game cannot be reccomended enough if you like Metroidvania and Platformer hybrids, even if you don't, who knows maybe Cave Story can change that!

As such, i shall grant this game, the fabled...
CURLY'S PANTIES/10

reviewText:
Это отличная игра за свои деньги и лучшая в этом жанре из тех, в которые я играл.
Плюсы:
Оригинальная идея с опытом. Это единственная игра, в которой я намного больше следил за уровнем, чем за здоровьем (за ним вообще не следил, если честно, так что было много глупых смертей ради опыта).
Тонна секретов. Я не нашёл ни один серьёзный секрет, хоть и осмотрел все углы в большинстве уровней.
3 концовки (сразу предупрежу, что хорошую без гайда почти невозможно получить, так что готовьтесь к очень грустным и неоправданным событиям).
Отличный баланс между стрельбой и платформером (но стрельбы всё равно больше, особенно в конце игры). Обычно в подобных играх всё время надоедают однообразные прыжки по платформам, либо однообразное мочилово, тут же я всю игру прошёл, даже немного не теряя интереса.
Разные уровни сложности, что редко встречается в платформерах.
Хороший сандутрек.
Выбор между новой и старой графикой и музыкой.Минусы:
Чтобы получить хорошую концовку, нужно сделать не очень логичное действие, а после этого тщательно подумать в одном месте. Ну или воспользоваться гайдом.
Некоторые задания заставляют ходить по одной и той же локации кругами. На лёгкой сложности это не было проблемой, но на средней это ад.
Очень маленькое разрешение. Мне это совершенно не помешало, но я представляю, как это должно быть ужасно для людей с 4К.Эта игра на лёгком закончилась всего за 4 часа, но смогла вызвать лёгкую депрессию. Слишком впечатлительным лучше не играть.
P.S. Оригинальная игра бесплатна. Здесь лишь новая музыка, новые текстурки и несколько бесполезных фич. Но в оригинале Мимиги не такие милые, так что советую купить.

reviewText:
The Pros:

- Gameplay is fun, oringal and enjoyable
- The story is an original and enjoyable story
- There are multiple endings towards the game
- There are collectibles as well as challenges that add extra replay value
- Great soundtrack

The Cons:

- Game is really hard at certain parts due to not having a lot of save locations (more towards the ending. spent 5 hours alone trying to beat it)
- Other than that, I cant think of any other cons

The Verdict: 9.5/10

If you love 2D platformers, then you will enjoy Cave Story +. The remastered graphics and soundtrack are a very big improvment over the orignal cave story, and they sound and look beautiful and immersive. Just prepare to die a lot though.

reviewText:
The game I've loved since I was in my mid-teens...where do I begin?

A platformer originally made in 2004 by one Japanese man named Daisuke Amaya. He has made several other games in this retro style, but this is one of his largest, and obviously most successful, projects.

What I love: The retro theme, the silky-smooth gameplay, the music, the corny little story, the items, the endings, the characters, the secrets, and the fact that you can still pick up the original for free. Legally!

What I hate: I can't have sex with it ._.

If you like platformers, I would give the free version a look. And if you love that, then consider throwing some money at this version :) There's extra little game modes, and the graphics are given a facelift. Besides, Pixel-san needs more recognition! HYPE THE PIXEL!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: As one of the greatest achievements in indie design, Cave Story is a charming, yet challenging pinnacle of the 2d platforming genre. From the cute and endearing characters, to the well thought-out story and level design, it just boggles my mind that this masterpiece was the work of just one person. In such an overwrought and bloated industry, Cave Story reassures us that indeed, simple is best.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic! Well worth the money at any price. For starters, many of you have probably played this game for free in the past. This was a freeware game long ago, and this is the best known indy game of all time. Now before you say anything, it is worth the money, and this version is so much better than the free version.

reviewText:
No doubt one of the best indie games out there.
As a fan of the old NES Megaman and Castlevania games I really enjoyed the gameplay with multiple weapon 3-level upgrades and sidescrolling cave exploration.
Things start getting even more interesting and trickier when you get the Booster, which is a jetpack of sorts. Add to that a touching story that makes you care for the characters, where your actions & decisions shape which ending you get.
I already had played the free version, but Pixel, the sole creator of the game, definitely deserves the credit for his hard work over the span of 5 years. Plus, there's the extra content! A must play.

reviewText:
I started the game and immediately saw those Japanese characters. I
was like, oh my god, another JRPG, or some other game I don't
understand. But I gave it a shot. After couple of minutes, it felt
like boring platformer with pixel graphics. Then something changed and
I'm still surprised how good is this game.

It is quite complex, story is rich, game has different endings, stages
are nonlinear. It is really joy to play. There are even some RPG
elements. Weapons are upgradable and they are quite different, so
there is time and place for every item from your arsenal. Boss fights
are hard, challenging, and most importantly fun. Just more checkpoints
would be nice (some traps are instant death).

Highly recommended.

The game does have the What do i do and where do i go" moments in it

reviewText:
I'm sort of biased about this game.

I say this because I played it before it was on Steam. As a freeware PC game, it was top notch. Hard to believe the original was made by just 1 guy. However, this isn't the original release I'm reviewing and they charge 14.99 for this version.

The game itself is some sort of a strange hybrid of Run N' Gun platforming mixed with Metroidvania, as the whole game is just 1 huge level with some backtracking is required to obtain certain items.

The controls themselves are excellent and there is a nice variety of different weapons you can use. Also, the minimalistic graphics and chiptune soundtrack give the game a unique retro vibe which is either hit-or-miss, depending on whether you like 8 bit games. The game does come with 2 graphic modes and 3 versions of the soundtrack though, so you can adjust the feel of the game somewhat if you feel inclined to.

At about a third through the game, following a plot twist, the game starts gaining momentum. The plot becomes darker, the bactracking becomes a lot less common, your arsenal starts growing to a nice size, and the game becomes a joy to play, with more varied environments, more challenging enemies, and epic boss battles.

My main issue with the game is it's first third. During your first few hours of the game, your arsenal is very limited, you backtrack through the same environments over and over on fetch quests, and fight the same enemies. This part of the game greatly highlights it's low budget and repeatedly recycled assets. However, if you endure enough to get over this frustrating part of the game, you're in for a treat as the following parts of the game are excellent.

Another minor gripe I have with the game is how easy it is to miss the best ending. The game has 4 endings (same as the original), and getting the best one will probably require a guide, as reaching it is very unintuitive and much harder to do than any of the others.

I have a problem recommending this one. As much as I love the later parts of the game, this Steam release doesn't really add much content, and the earlier segments of the game might make you lose interest before you get to the good parts. I recommend you try the original, free version, as it's basically the same game without some modern conveniences.

If you enjoy that one, like I did, and a higher resolution, new soundtrack, and an additional level justify the 15$ for you, I say go for it.

reviewText:
The game I've loved since I was in my mid-teens...where do I begin?

A platformer originally made in 2004 by one Japanese man named Daisuke Amaya. He has made several other games in this retro style, but this is one of his largest, and obviously most successful, projects.

What I love: The retro theme, the silky-smooth gameplay, the music, the corny little story, the items, the endings, the characters, the secrets, and the fact that you can still pick up the original for free. Legally!

What I hate: I can't have sex with it ._.

If you like platformers, I would give the free version a look. And if you love that, then consider throwing some money at this version :) There's extra little game modes, and the graphics are given a facelift. Besides, Pixel-san needs more recognition! HYPE THE PIXEL!

reviewText:
The Pros:

- Gameplay is fun, oringal and enjoyable
- The story is an original and enjoyable story
- There are multiple endings towards the game
- There are collectibles as well as challenges that add extra replay value
- Great soundtrack

The Cons:

- Game is really hard at certain parts due to not having a lot of save locations (more towards the ending. spent 5 hours alone trying to beat it)
- Other than that, I cant think of any other cons

The Verdict: 9.5/10

If you love 2D platformers, then you will enjoy Cave Story +. The remastered graphics and soundtrack are a very big improvment over the orignal cave story, and they sound and look beautiful and immersive. Just prepare to die a lot though.

reviewText:
An adorable game at sugar-high inducing levels of cuteness, it also provides a shockingly (at least, shockingly next to all the cuteness) dark setting underneath. While the silent protagonist is quite overdone by Japanese style games, it's still interesting to see the exchanges between characters and whatnot.

The gameplay itself is nice. In the midst of all the 3D games, it's nice to have a 2D sidescroller once in a while, and it's quite reminiscent of games such as Metroid or whatnot. It's unique in that you have different levels for the weapons that you can lose by being hit (so there's encouragement to avoid attacks beyond hp) and gained by eating doritos. The gameplay mainly speaks more for itself, in any case. Also, the gameplay strikes a nice balance with difficulty. It becomes extremely difficult at times, but not overwhelmingly so. Of course, if you want to go for best ending... heh. Good luck.

So, it's worth a try at least. Hell, the original is free if you don't want to spend $ or £ or whatever, though + refines the cuteness.

reviewText:
I know I'm late to the Cave Story party but this game is great and I was surprised by its quality. Cave Story is a 2D side-scroller/run n' gun where you progress by exploring, defeating enemies, finding items and beating the many boss fights. Although this may all sound run of the mill, the strengths of the game lie in its mechanics. Although it is inspired by retro platformers it is not an amalgamation of several retro platformers, instead doing its own thing. An example of this would be the levelling system of the game's weapons, where they are levelled up by collecting xp drops from enemies, but xp is lost when you take damage, and the weapon can even level down again. This makes for an interesting mechanic, where there are higher stakes to getting hit than there usually is in a modern platformer.

The weapon balance is great. No weapon entirely replaces another as they each have their own pros and cons, and are useful in different situations, For example, the rocket launcher can pummel through enemies but it takes awhile to level it up and it is reliant on a limited ammo supply. The second of this game's biggest strengths is the level design, which is on point. The difficulty curve is smooth and the levels are filled with a variety of secrets and surprises, the boss fights are placed so as to surprise the player and keep them on their toes, as any retro-styled game should.

Finally, the game has a charming art style and cast of memorable characters, which I would go on about more but I am more concerned with the gameplay here. Unfortunately, the game is not without its faults. First and foremost, the controls feel very floaty at the best of times. It isn't too hard to get accustomed to the floatiness of the controls, and most people won't even notice it, but for someone like me who plays a lot of run n' gun-style arcade games this can put me off, and I feel like much of the game's difficulty comes from the floatiness rather than actual design (most of the game's difficulty is legitimate however).

Secondly, the three difficulty options presented to the player are not fleshed out, since they only affect how much damage you take from being hit, rather than changing the design of the game to make it more or less skill-demanding. This is likely because the original freeware version did not have different difficulty options, therefore the publisher of CS+ tacked them on.  The other big issue concerning difficulty is the frequency of the save points. They are just too frequent. It is only at the final part of the game where save points are scarce, for most of the game you will never go long without a save point. This reduces the otherwise high-stakes of the game and makes death feel disappointly lenient. Again most people won't mind this but those looking for high-stakes action should keep it in mind.

This is not so much an issue with the game, but with the localisation. The official translation by nicalis is terrible and strips away most of the charm of the character cast and setting. If you want to play this game don't do what I did, play with the official translation. What you're gonna want to do is download a fanmade translation and extract it to the game's directory on steam. There are other steam guides to help you through the process, and trust me you will be happier for having done it.

Overall, Cave Story is easy to recommend for just about anyone interested in a hardcore platformer/run n' gun with great level design and weapon balance, and a charming visual style.

1st lets establish what this game is https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1emSWVcSu8s (Warning Minor spoilers)
So now we have an understanding what this game is about let’s move to the next subject
Also if you want my opinions on the story, it’s probably one of the best video game tales ever told

Gameplay:
-The only game I have ever play that has a similar control scheme to this game is Awesomenauts and even that it’s a bit farfetched.
-Unlike in Awesomnauts (where you aim with your mouse) you control your directions via arrows keys with no diangular directions

Weapons:
-You have 6 weapons on yourself late game with 4 you can upgrade/ trade off if you want to on your journey.
-Each weapon is extremely fun and unique with some being more than others but all weapons have their place in the world where it would be the most efficient
-Each weapon can be level up to 3 times by collecting triangle bits that fall out of each enemy (XP)
In most cases higher levels mean more damage and more ability power for the weapon (I won't spoil the effects for you)
-Some weapons level in different ways (mostly late game)
-When you get hit by the enemy your XP on your weapon goes down by a certain amount, different weapons level faster and different weapons lose more when you get hit (kinda like armor effect)

Other:
-The games life system is based on health and invincibility frames after getting hit, health is restored usually on enemy drops or in map pickups.
-Mid game the difficulty curve shoots up like a ♥♥♥♥ing rocket ship, it mellows out after that part but the very last level (The secret ending) is near impossible to do without hours-days of practice and knowledge. I would highly recommended to look up a speedrun and/or walkthrough of that part if you’re getting stuck on a certain section of it (especially with the very last 2 parts because you have 10 seconds to figure it out and to many ways to mess up). The 1st 3 parts of it is UNfairly challenging and can be learn given enough time.


Soundtrack/OST:
One of the best OSTs ever made IMO, be sure to have the game set to “Remaster”
http://cavestory.wikia.com/wiki/Version_differences <-- If you want to know about the different versions of this game and their assets.


Main Problem with the game:
-The branching paths... The paths are few and far between but taking the wrong path will give you the lesser ending + weaker items (and nothing more)
-The paths are not obvious which mean you can end up making a mistake where you end up deeply regretting latter (which usually leads to messing with trainers to get back where you want to be)
-So with this I have to regrettable say, it’s in your best interest to grab a guide that at least tells you about these branching paths and which ones to take.


Conclusion:
Overlooking the game problems, I think this is a game that EVERYONE should play/try.
-IMO there’s something whimsical about this game that makes it special for me and also IMO it would be unfair to yourselves if you went on living without never touching this game.

reviewText:
Did you know Cave Story was made by one man? To be honest, you probably did, but if not, you should be impressed.
I enjoyed this game a LOT, my hours should pretty much be the evidence for that. The gameplay is pretty addicting, it isn't easy, but not too hard either (for the most part, atleast).

However, the original version of the game - found at http://www.cavestory.org/ - is free and it's pretty much the same with the exception of challenges and runs at 50fps, while the Cave Story+ version runs at 60fps. As a player of both versions, I got to say, I enjoyed the CS+ version more.

If you don't like the remastered" graphics or soundtrack you can always change them to original (in the soundtrack

reviewText: Cave Story is probably one of the first PC games that I ever really played. I love the soundtrack, the graphics, the gameplay, and everything else. This makes the game good but when you realize that all of this was done by one man within a course of 5 years, that's when it gets set apart from the other titles like it. The game originally came out as freeware, but now they have improved upon everything that I listed above and made the game that much more enjoyable. Controller support, enhanced soundtrack and better graphics make this game worth its price. It's about time that Pixel gets the money he deserves.\n\nGreat game
