reviewText:
I'm sort of biased about this game.

I say this because I played it before it was on Steam. As a freeware PC game, it was top notch. Hard to believe the original was made by just 1 guy. However, this isn't the original release I'm reviewing and they charge 14.99 for this version.

The game itself is some sort of a strange hybrid of Run N' Gun platforming mixed with Metroidvania, as the whole game is just 1 huge level with some backtracking is required to obtain certain items.

The controls themselves are excellent and there is a nice variety of different weapons you can use. Also, the minimalistic graphics and chiptune soundtrack give the game a unique retro vibe which is either hit-or-miss, depending on whether you like 8 bit games. The game does come with 2 graphic modes and 3 versions of the soundtrack though, so you can adjust the feel of the game somewhat if you feel inclined to.

At about a third through the game, following a plot twist, the game starts gaining momentum. The plot becomes darker, the bactracking becomes a lot less common, your arsenal starts growing to a nice size, and the game becomes a joy to play, with more varied environments, more challenging enemies, and epic boss battles.

My main issue with the game is it's first third. During your first few hours of the game, your arsenal is very limited, you backtrack through the same environments over and over on fetch quests, and fight the same enemies. This part of the game greatly highlights it's low budget and repeatedly recycled assets. However, if you endure enough to get over this frustrating part of the game, you're in for a treat as the following parts of the game are excellent.

Another minor gripe I have with the game is how easy it is to miss the best ending. The game has 4 endings (same as the original), and getting the best one will probably require a guide, as reaching it is very unintuitive and much harder to do than any of the others.

I have a problem recommending this one. As much as I love the later parts of the game, this Steam release doesn't really add much content, and the earlier segments of the game might make you lose interest before you get to the good parts. I recommend you try the original, free version, as it's basically the same game without some modern conveniences.

If you enjoy that one, like I did, and a higher resolution, new soundtrack, and an additional level justify the 15$ for you, I say go for it.

reviewText: Reminiscent of old-school Metroid or Castlevania games, this is an extremely fun game and gets very challenging in the later stages without becoming too frustrating. The system that has your weapons leveling up as enemies fall and losing levels when damage is taken adds a nice strategic depth (as a boss might hit you one too many times and render your favorite weapon almost worthless). The story is also very well-written and does a good job of immersing you in the game world.

reviewText:
insert shut up and take my money copypasta here







This game is really a great experience. I discovered it on the DSiWare shop on my Nintendo DSi 5 years ago, and I bought it. I then moved onto the freeware version from the fansite, and now I've gotten my hands on this - Cave Story+. It's a great game that mixes a great story with great platforming. And best of all, it has many different weapons.

Speaking of many differing things.. it has a bunch of endings too.

What really brought me to obtain this game (thanks to a friend) was the extra content. Whether it be challenges or the new remastered soundtrack and sprites, you're gonna find something new here.

But what truly made me want this is Curly Story. I mean come on, Curly Brace is the best.

But in all seriousness, I'd recommend this to anyone. I've had a lot of experience with this game (on the freeware version), I've played through it with every possible weapon combination and I try to always aim for the best ending possible. It's an experience that you ultimately decide on how it plays out.

reviewText:
I know I'm late to the Cave Story party but this game is great and I was surprised by its quality. Cave Story is a 2D side-scroller/run n' gun where you progress by exploring, defeating enemies, finding items and beating the many boss fights. Although this may all sound run of the mill, the strengths of the game lie in its mechanics. Although it is inspired by retro platformers it is not an amalgamation of several retro platformers, instead doing its own thing. An example of this would be the levelling system of the game's weapons, where they are levelled up by collecting xp drops from enemies, but xp is lost when you take damage, and the weapon can even level down again. This makes for an interesting mechanic, where there are higher stakes to getting hit than there usually is in a modern platformer.

The weapon balance is great. No weapon entirely replaces another as they each have their own pros and cons, and are useful in different situations, For example, the rocket launcher can pummel through enemies but it takes awhile to level it up and it is reliant on a limited ammo supply. The second of this game's biggest strengths is the level design, which is on point. The difficulty curve is smooth and the levels are filled with a variety of secrets and surprises, the boss fights are placed so as to surprise the player and keep them on their toes, as any retro-styled game should.

Finally, the game has a charming art style and cast of memorable characters, which I would go on about more but I am more concerned with the gameplay here. Unfortunately, the game is not without its faults. First and foremost, the controls feel very floaty at the best of times. It isn't too hard to get accustomed to the floatiness of the controls, and most people won't even notice it, but for someone like me who plays a lot of run n' gun-style arcade games this can put me off, and I feel like much of the game's difficulty comes from the floatiness rather than actual design (most of the game's difficulty is legitimate however).

Secondly, the three difficulty options presented to the player are not fleshed out, since they only affect how much damage you take from being hit, rather than changing the design of the game to make it more or less skill-demanding. This is likely because the original freeware version did not have different difficulty options, therefore the publisher of CS+ tacked them on.  The other big issue concerning difficulty is the frequency of the save points. They are just too frequent. It is only at the final part of the game where save points are scarce, for most of the game you will never go long without a save point. This reduces the otherwise high-stakes of the game and makes death feel disappointly lenient. Again most people won't mind this but those looking for high-stakes action should keep it in mind.

This is not so much an issue with the game, but with the localisation. The official translation by nicalis is terrible and strips away most of the charm of the character cast and setting. If you want to play this game don't do what I did, play with the official translation. What you're gonna want to do is download a fanmade translation and extract it to the game's directory on steam. There are other steam guides to help you through the process, and trust me you will be happier for having done it.

Overall, Cave Story is easy to recommend for just about anyone interested in a hardcore platformer/run n' gun with great level design and weapon balance, and a charming visual style.

This game is by far amazing. The story, the music, the secrets, the endings. ALL OF IT. It is truly amazing. Further details is that this game also has a level up system which goes up to level 3 max, but its more focused on weapons rather than your character. Its really good.

I'm glad I came across this game and decided to buy it, I hope you all consider buying this.

reviewText:
Incredible. This is, without a doubt, the best indie game I've ever played.

Storyline(s)The multiple endings are all very well developed. Although there is more than one endings, te endings don't effect the gameplay negatively. This game masterfully avoids too many endings, unlike some other games, where, simply for the sake of adding endings, the creators forget to make their game playable.

GameplayThis game is very engaging. It keeps you wanting more, while not revealing too much to the point where the playthrough feels mindless. The replayability is astounding, because, although the location and dialogue don't change much throughout different playthroughs, as you become more experienced, you are able to find many more aspects that were originally, seemingly, hidden.

AchievementsThe addition of acheivement is Cave Story+ from Cave Story is luxurious. Although, not necessary, the achievements are a very powerful driving factor in the exploration of the game. These achievements aren't just mindless rewards given out for any task, but instead, vary in difficult, presenting a challenge to achievement collectors.

Extra FeaturesThe additional features added in Cave Story+ (Curly Mode, Machine Gun Challenge, ect.) are all very engaging and are a good reason to keep coming back. They all leave a bit of a mystery that is intruiging enough for a player to want to replay this game, over and over and over, while still being excited about each playthrough.

Although I do realise that I gave a very brief review, I believe that I covered important aspects of the game. Over all, this game is a perfect 10/10.

reviewText:
I first played Cave Story when it was a Japanese freeware game with a fan translation, probably around 2005 or so. It wss a great game then, and Cave Story+ is perhaps better.

The game itself is a solid platformer, challenging, yet fair. The story is decent; by no means stellar, but not bad either.

Cave Story+ adds graphical and musical improvements to the original, as well as additiona game modes, challenges, and difficulty settings. Additionally, there is the option to use the original graphics and music, so fans of the original can still play it as such.

All in all, A solid game worth giving a playthrough or two.

reviewText: Everything about Cave Story hearkens back to the glory days of the SNES/Super Famicom. The lovingly hand-crafted graphics and catchy chiptune soundtrack create a vibrant 16 bit" environment. The storyline is interesting and quirky
date: with a distinctly Japanese flavor. Gameplay is somewhere between a "metroidvania" platformer and a "bullet hell" shoot-em-up: platforming challenges mix with a unique weapons upgrade system which rewards skillful dodging and punishes the slightest misstep with power-downs. There are certainly challenges to be had on higher difficulties
recommended: but those who just want to coast through the story will find options which suit them as well.\n\nInconvenient save point locations can make difficult areas a bit of a grind
hoursPlayed: as you have to beat the same area over and over again to reach a boss fight or other difficult challenge
voteText: and the game does little other than drop hints to steer you towards your end goal. Perhaps the game's biggest flaw however is the length: a skilled gamer can breeze through easy difficulty in less than four hours. Certainly there is a lot of replayability
helpfulPercent: as one can increase the difficulty level or make different choices in storyline progression
votesHelpful: but one must certainly have a strong appreciation for that type of repetition to endure.\n\nOverall Cave Story is a rewarding experience for gamers who yearn for secrets to discover

votesFunny: skill-based challenges

reviewText:
Great game!
But it's free if you know how to google.

I stick to the stupid purist idea that you should play this game on at least original music, if you don't go wholly into original everything for cave story.

The skill ramp is somewhat perfect with little deviation,
And the game has a great story with multiple endings, (with the true ending being arguably impossible to naturally achieve on your first playthrough without a guide.)

Don't be an idiot, don't pay 15 for it, but buy and play it nonetheless.

Extra: This creator of this game created this in his spare time over 4 years. He also created a music-creating software for this game and another game called Ika-Chan. (Both of these can be found on the cave-story fan website, google is your friend.) He also released this game for free, along with all of the software previously described. I'm not sure what his intention was, but if I had to guess it probably had to do with altruism and entertainment.
Phil Fish made Fez in the same timeframe but with crappy unoriginal internet funnies and other despicable internet culture gimmicks.
He also charged money from the get-go.

reviewText:
Cave Story is a fantastic throwback of nostalgia with a mix of combat and platforming that is well worth the $10.

The story is simple, but that's fine. You're this little guy that wakes up with no memory of what happened and you find that a race of bunny people (Mimigas) are being abducted from a mad scientist for experiments. You must save them.

And how you save them, is the main reason you should buy the game: Sega Genesis/SNES combat in a modern title. There is a variety of different weapons ranging from missile launchers, to pea shooters, to a mario styled fireball thing. The other mechanic in this is platforming, but true" platforming that is reminiscent of Super Mario and Meat Boy is only present when you're trying to get to power ups
date: etc. It is more combat focused but that doesn't affect gameplay.\n\nBeing a nostalgic throwback
recommended: Cave Story's graphics pop. If you can get over it being purposefully pixellated
hoursPlayed: you should enjoy the bright colors of the overworld and gloomy atmosphere of the caves. This does run in 1080p and the pixels are sharp - something that a game like this NEEDS. It runs fine on my rig
voteText: but that doesn't mean anything. It probably will run smoothly on a 5 year old Windows XP machine
helpfulPercent: since it is not a demanding game.\n\nIf you've grown up with sidescrolling shooters like Metroid and Castlevania
votesHelpful: then this is definitely something you should pick up.\n\n8.5/10"

reviewText: I went into this game expecting a fun little pixelated platformer indie game, but got an absolute masterpiece. Everything about this game is done right. EVERYTHING. reviewText:
Note: I've completed this game twice on the original PC version and twice on the DS version, now I'm going to attempt 100% on the Steam version.

This game is my favourite game of all time, I've poured hours into it in the past, and I will be doing so again now and in the future. The soundtrack of this game remains my favourite, Pulse and Geothermal are my top two tracks, and I have the entire soundtrack on my phone to listen to sometimes. I play this game with the original music and visuals, because it feels nostalgic somehow, so I can't give much input into the remastered versions of the two. Curly is an awesome character, and genuinely pulls on your heart strings at times throughout the game, and all the other characters grow lovable too, even the villains. The gameplay is a mixture of megaman and castlevania, or better known as the genre 'metroidvania', which wouldn't usually appeal to me, but does somehow. There are a wide variety of weapons to find throughout the game, some requiring restarts of the game to get, since it's a pick-this-or-that type thing, which is fine because there's fairly good replayability, and plenty of achievements to get alongside your restarts.

Probably 200+ hours of game time if you're dedicated to getting 100%, definitely worth the price, more so on sale. I more than recommend this game to anybody wanting a retro indie game with an amazing story, solid characters and a perfect soundtrack. 10/10 for sure, in my books.

reviewText:
Great game!
But it's free if you know how to google.

I stick to the stupid purist idea that you should play this game on at least original music, if you don't go wholly into original everything for cave story.

The skill ramp is somewhat perfect with little deviation,
And the game has a great story with multiple endings, (with the true ending being arguably impossible to naturally achieve on your first playthrough without a guide.)

Don't be an idiot, don't pay 15 for it, but buy and play it nonetheless.

Extra: This creator of this game created this in his spare time over 4 years. He also created a music-creating software for this game and another game called Ika-Chan. (Both of these can be found on the cave-story fan website, google is your friend.) He also released this game for free, along with all of the software previously described. I'm not sure what his intention was, but if I had to guess it probably had to do with altruism and entertainment.
Phil Fish made Fez in the same timeframe but with crappy unoriginal internet funnies and other despicable internet culture gimmicks.
He also charged money from the get-go.

reviewText:
Superb for its time and still pretty good by today's standards.

Cave Story+ excels in many of the major categories you'd rate it in. It's written with a lot of wit and charm. The gameplay is fun with a wide range of weapons that give you a lot of utility. Level design is varied and keeps things interesting and challenging. The soundtrack is a nostalgic trip into chiptune goodness.

It does have some flaws though. Its challenge mode is broken for me and many other players by crashing as soon as I reach the finish of the first challenge. Don't expect this to be patched as it's been known for a long time and nothing has been done about it. I'm also not impressed with its graphics. They're not terrible, in fact some of the character designs might be called cute, but many of the environments are drab mixes of grays and browns. I generally found the soundtrack catchy but there were a few tunes that became annoying.

Playing on original" difficulty I thought that the combat had a satisfying level of challenge to it. However
date: the amount of damage you take from environmental dangers like spikes was too harsh in my view. There are numerous traps that will kill you in one shot no matter how much health you have. That is more unforgiving than I like
recommended: especially in a game with slightly floaty controls. Fortunately
hoursPlayed: the controls are consistent throughout the game so you can adapt to them and they become more manageable once you get the booster. Keeping with the old school  theme you are unable to shoot diagonally
voteText: only in the four cardinal directions.\n\nI'd like to close by bringing special attention to the rich world that is explored in Cave Story+. There's a fascinating backstory to discover as you play as well as fun characters to interact with. As with most "Metroidvania" games there are plenty of hidden and optional areas but here you won't just find power-ups. There are side quests
helpfulPercent: additional lore
votesHelpful: optional weapons and gear
votesTotal: and even events that can lead to different endings for the game. This is a dream for players that love to dig into all the details of a game."

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10
OVerview: 2d Side Scrolling Action/Platformer

The Good:

+ On the surface this game may seem like a standard 2d action game, however once you dig deeper you realize there is more to this little game than you originally thought. As you play you are given choices throughout the game that not only impact the story but even what weapons you can use. All of this leads to some good replaybility and is probably the games' biggest asset

+The game has somewhat of a unique upgrade system for the weapons you use. As you kill enemies they drop experience that will increase your weapons level. Each weapon has 3 levels each one getting progressively better. However if you get hit by an enemy your weapon level decreases adding an extra level of complexity to the game.

+ A variety of different weapons that fit your play style or situation.

+ The game controls are fantastic and feel very responsive

+ The game has some really great boss battles, the further you progress in the game the more diverse and unique they become

+The game provides a lot of different modes after you beat the game. Each mode requires you to beat it in a certain amount of time, the better you do, the more achievements you get. This further adds to the reaplayability to the game.

The Average:

Level design and objectives are not that good. Most of the levels have you running to one end of the map only to run back to the beginning again to complete certain objectives and advance the story.  This adds nothing to the gameplay and seems only to be used to pad out the game length. It gets tiring after a while.

The Bad:

- I really disliked the story and characters. Nothing seems to make sense and about half way through the game I couldn't care what happens to anybody.

Conclusion

I  had a lot of fun with the game, I just wish the levels were better designed. The extra modes provided are also fun.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Excellent                                                           AESTHETIC: Retro
MEMORABILITY: Quintessential                              WORTH: Discounted

PROS: Classically-driven Japanese style story that is a touch melancholy, but not nauseatingly-so. Excellent controls and interesting characters. Several soundtrack choices as well as an option for the original graphics. Multiple outcomes for decisions made, as well as weapon options.

CONS: Steep difficulty curve near the end is extremely frustrating. Similar to Eversion, you're mainly paying for graphical update and soundtrack options; the entire original game is free.  Many will also tell you that this version of the game has unlikeable dialogue changes. Mac players have been having trouble with it as well.

OVERALL: Charming fantasy sci-fi that shows that 2D platformers with pixel art and limited palettes don't have be outcast to the realm of dated" or "niche." Cave Story was made with a lot of love which has turned it into an outstanding addition to any library. If you feel that supporting this version of the game is wrong for one reason or the other
date: you may find your money better spent on "Kero Blaster

reviewText: Great game, would have been one of the best NES games of all time if it had come out in the early 90ies.  Instead its a modern day throwback to all that was great about NES platformers/action games, from gameplay (tight on a gamepad), to sound (fun music), to story (interesting and somewhat deep story for a act/platformer), to really cute 8 bit pixelated graphics.  The game does require fairly good reflexes and skill, however I was able to get through it with a decent but not overwhelming challenge on easy, bump up the difficulty if you have the skill.

reviewText:
The world's most popular doujin game.

For good reason, too.

This side-scrolling Metroidvania has you playing as Quote, an amnesiac robot who is trying to recover his memory while helping the island natives.

The OST is wonderful, and in this version you can pick from remixes or the original chiptune songs, both of which are pretty damn good.

Graphically, the updated visuals are nice, though being able to return to the original sprites and such was a very welcome addition.

Cave Story lends itself well to replayability, with speed-running, time trials and various different endings and choices.


I really can't recommend this game enough. This game's pretty damn fun. It's also oddly cozy, if you're into that.

reviewText:
I recently reviewed this game for my game review blog, Five Penny Review. If you enjoy this review, please visit my page:
http://fivepennyreview.blogspot.com/2012/10/cave-story.html

What sets this game apart?
Independent developer Pixel spent five years working on this game in his free time, by himself, and produced a game with a compelling story and great retro platforming.  The popularity Cave Story achieved as a freeware title went a long way in proving to the gaming market that you can get a quality product without shelling out $50 to the big production companies.  Surely, this title paved the way for a variety of Xbox Live Arcade, Steam, and even Humble Indy Bundle titles.

What is the difficulty factor?
Cave Story plays like you would expect most games of its type to play, so there is no tutorial level.  The creator designed the first area in a way to “lets players feel like they've solved problems on their own.”  While it may seem frustrating to learn the hard way that those red spikes will in fact kill you instantly, or that you went the wrong way and have to double back before you can progress, it isn’t like you lose anything for dying, and there are only two ways to go anyway.  Using this sort of tough love tutorial might leave you feeling challenged, but ultimately more accomplished from the very beginning of the game, which sets the tone for the rest of the game.

There is certainly no shortage of challenge, here, and even veteran players will experience a few moments where they may feel like pulling their hair out.  Collecting all of the hidden items and choosing the strongest weapons will go a long way in making you successful, but gathering them is a challenging endeavor in itself.  If you are feeling complacent with the difficulty, aim for the secret “good” ending, which features an impossibly difficult series of platforming feats.  In later ports, “hard” mode and a boss run time trial were added for the truly masochistic.

Does it use media effectively?
While the graphics and music have an enjoyable retro feel to them, and were produced by a single creator, I have to admit that they are not up to par with the technology available.  Later versions, notably Cave Story+ on Steam, cleaned up the graphics and sound while still keeping the retro feel that made it so enjoyable.  The most recent version, a port to the 3DS, was built from the ground up with rendered graphics, stereoscopic 3D, and additional content.  All of the versions are still enjoyable and feature the same level design and gameplay, so just pick the one that fits your visual preference and the limitations of your wallet.

Best moment in the game?
There are a lot of good moments in this game, but I’m going to have to say that the best moment to me is the boss fight at the end of Sand Zone.  To me, this is the point when the story proves how serious it is going to be.  The dialogue with King and Toroko at this point really hits home, and as the first act comes to a close, you are pumped up and ready to take down the Doctor.

Who needs to play this game?
This is a modern classic that almost any gamer will enjoy.  Take an NES classic like Metroid, add a compelling story and a bit more linear exploration pattern.  If you have a computer, you have no excuse not to play it, since the original game with a fan translated patch is still available for free (http://www.cavestory.org/downloads_game.php)!  If you are willing to spend a few bucks, I would personally suggest getting your hands on the DSi or Steam release, as they have some additional features that extend the replayability of the game.

reviewText: What started as a freeware platform-adventure game has ended up on Steam in 2011, an enhanced version of the original game Cave Story. This is a great platformer with engaging storyline, unique set of characters, funny and well-written dialogue, an arsenal of inventive weapons, secret chambers, chests and upgrades, humongous range of bosses to fight agains. The game features three different endings and two graphical settings to choose from: original or remastered; as well as three types of soundtrack: original, remastered and brand new one written especially for Wii release of the game. It's worth checking out this game if you have some free time and want to take a break from all the Call of Duties, Medal of Honors and Battlefields.

reviewText: Cave Story is an old freeware platformer that comes highly recommended. A very decent platformer in the style of metroid, with a faster paced feel to it, and an interesting story that builds up as you play. It gets very hard towards the end though, depending on the decisions you make\n\nCave Story+ is basically Cave Story with better graphics, and a remixed soundtrack which I don't like as much as the old one. It's also got a new translation which I think is better, but others disagree. It's got some new levels that you can't play till you complete the game on Normal, and an easy difficulty level which is nice. Still, it's not particularly good value when compared to free

reviewText:
I don't really play these types of games but this was bloody awesome, the unique style of gameplay, a terrific well written story, the environment and design, the outstanding and memorable music makes this game an old school legend.

If this game would have been released in the old days it would have competed and won over most Nintendo titles by far. The maker put such detail into everything and there's always something new about it.

It also features multiple storytelling and depending on how you choose to interact with everyone and what items you collect and do what not with will affect the game. The game is an open world to explore!

MetaScore: 110/100
imdbScore: 8.0/10

reviewText:
For a game that was produced entirely by one man, it is outstanding. The music is wonderfully catchy, and the visuals are simplistic yet stylized, and quite frankly, adorable.

The original version of the game was produced and released entirely free, and is still available today. The +/plus version of the game, available here on steam, includes an entirely re-drawn HD texture set, and three different versions for the music. You can switch between any of these options in the main menu, and it doesn't effect your save in any way.

I would high reccomend that you play with a controller, as the game is notably more difficult with the keyboard. There are certain mechanics that allow you to shoot towards the ground and fly up like a jetpack, but there is also a jetpack that you can use on top of that, and in the end it really does feel much more precise with a controller of some sort. I'd reccomend the PS3 pad as the D-pad feels the best, but anything should be fine.

Aside from the incredibly satisfying and decently challenging gameplay, one of the most amazing things is that the game gives you choices, and in really the best way possible. Its not a conversation dialog where you select option A or option B, its a story that branches based on various factors and decisions that you make a long the way. At what you feel is the end of the game, you are given the option to just follow someone and and escape unharmed, or you can go a different and much more challenging path, to save the people in need. There are various endings and items and weapons that you can miss entirely. This is a game that you will want to play through multiple times to experience the different endings. I'd reccomend that you play game game once, and then google what you need to do to see the other endings, because I would imagine it would be quite difficult to figure out these paths on your own. Some even involve completely denying good things that you usually get early on.

reviewText:
This is a spectacular game, and it hits many high notes. It has the platforming of Mario, the puzzle-solving of Metroid, the exploration of a sandbox game, and the combat system of Mega Man.

It's your decision if you want to get the freeware version with one difficulty and no extras, or you can use 10$ to get Cave Story+, which adds plenty of new challenges, 76 achievements, 3 music settings, 2 graphic settings (Original or Remastered), and 3 difficulties. Cave Story+ is a must buy for anyone truly interested. I recommend it whole-heartedly.

If you still have trouble deciding, check out my Cave Story+ Let's Play on The Shiny Goomy! That will show you the game inside and out.

reviewText:
Some people might tell you this game is overrated. Those people are wrong.

Those people may not like the game, but to say that this game is overrated is an invalid opinion. Although this game is one of the primary reasons that the PC game market is oversaturated with indie platformers, Cave Story is truly in a league of its own compared to virtually all indie games. The remastered soundtrack sounds great, too.

From the get-go, it's obvious that Cave Story draws a lot from Castlevania and Metroid; it has the more-intense platforming of the former with the shooty guns of the latter. Like Symphony of the Night, it occasionally breaks up the action with a dialogue sequence. It also has key plot events that can be changed or prevented if the player is observant enough. Unlike SOTN, however, the characters, dialogue and story are actually memorable and meaningful. Like many Japanese games, it gets incredibly ♥♥♥♥ed up near the end. And it gets even more ♥♥♥♥ed up if you get the best ending.

Cave Story is short, but quite replayable, with plenty of hidden content. The plus edition adds even more, with a super-hard area (Wind Fortress) added in, amongst a few other little features. Having said that, this game is designed like an NES game, or perhaps like Dark Souls; which means that it's short, but because of the difficulty, you'll probably end up spending the same amount of time you would on this game as you would on a game with more content on your first playthrough. And believe me, you will most likely play through this game more than once.

This game was created by Daisuke Amaya over a five-year period in his spare time, and his talent is incredible. Not only is the game programmed well with no noticeable bugs or glitches to speak of, but the art looks great and the soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in years. As I mentioned before, the story elements of the game are also quite good. I definitely understand that it took him five years to make this, but even so, it's truly impressive that he was able to perform outstandingly on all aspects of the game development cycle.

I highly advise you have a gamepad of some kind before playing this game. I played through part of it with my keyboard, and after an hour and a half of playing it my fingers would actually start to hurt. Using your meaty thumbs on softer gamepad buttons will be much better for you in the long run.

reviewText: It has been a while since I played Cave Story. It is easily a great game for a metroidvania lover. I had not experienced such difficulty ever in a 2D platformer before. It is one of the  few games where I have come to terms with myself to give up on it, right on the final boss. I won't explain why due to spoilers, but those who have beaten it and I praise them for their patience, will deeply understand. It has a great soundtrack and it might look adorable, but do not be fooled. One of the toughest experiences I have had. I recently started playing Rogue Legacy and the fact that this game was hard, I remembered Cave Story and decided to review it. If you enjoy challenging games, this is definitely one of the top ones in my opinion.

reviewText:
For a game that was produced entirely by one man, it is outstanding. The music is wonderfully catchy, and the visuals are simplistic yet stylized, and quite frankly, adorable.

The original version of the game was produced and released entirely free, and is still available today. The +/plus version of the game, available here on steam, includes an entirely re-drawn HD texture set, and three different versions for the music. You can switch between any of these options in the main menu, and it doesn't effect your save in any way.

I would high reccomend that you play with a controller, as the game is notably more difficult with the keyboard. There are certain mechanics that allow you to shoot towards the ground and fly up like a jetpack, but there is also a jetpack that you can use on top of that, and in the end it really does feel much more precise with a controller of some sort. I'd reccomend the PS3 pad as the D-pad feels the best, but anything should be fine.

Aside from the incredibly satisfying and decently challenging gameplay, one of the most amazing things is that the game gives you choices, and in really the best way possible. Its not a conversation dialog where you select option A or option B, its a story that branches based on various factors and decisions that you make a long the way. At what you feel is the end of the game, you are given the option to just follow someone and and escape unharmed, or you can go a different and much more challenging path, to save the people in need. There are various endings and items and weapons that you can miss entirely. This is a game that you will want to play through multiple times to experience the different endings. I'd reccomend that you play game game once, and then google what you need to do to see the other endings, because I would imagine it would be quite difficult to figure out these paths on your own. Some even involve completely denying good things that you usually get early on.

reviewText: Cave Story+ is a famous Japanese independent game that was originally released as freeware with a fan translation. This re-release offers a choice of playing with the original graphics and music, or the remastered graphics and music. Whatever your choice may be, the game is a well done fanfare reminiscent of the classic platform games on the NES and SNES. The keyboard controls takes some getting used to even though they are simple to learn, but you do have the option of rebinding the keys and using a gamepad. The plot is comparable the well established lore of yesteryear by being invited to save people and rid a world of evil. The enemies are stereotypically Japanese in design, as well as the overall game mechanics and boss battles. Some of the dialog can be slightly amusing and sometimes charming, but this once again, does not steer too much away from what we have grown accustomed to enjoy from the 80s and 90s console eras. The difficulty settings can be adjusted to your liking, and they each provide an adequate challenge depending on what option you have decided to go for. The power-up system rewards the players who go out of their way to collect dropped items from downed foes. Switching between each weapon rapidly can be tricky, but this does not hinder the player from enjoying the changes, as adapting comes somewhat quickly through your progress. The different weapons acquired throughout the game are all quite useful and play very different from each other. As you change between them, there is much satisfaction shooting down your enemies and conquering bosses. While the storyline is reminiscent of past decades, it is surprisingly unique, in addition to flowing and developing well. This appealing plot provides the player with plenty of entertainment for many hours as you progress through the story. After tougher areas or tougher boss battles, your weapons' levels go down quite a bit as you take damage, and gathering the necessary drops in order to get them back to full power can be a chore. Cave Story+ is full of retro charm, from its game play style to its artistic inventions. There is very little to complain about, as I cannot think of any serious flaws. The resolution settings do not allow for true full screen, as black borders will be placed at the sides. The platforming elements in conjunction with the shooting can sometimes take some skill and getting used to, especially in high action sections. Some portions of the game (namely some bosses) become quite frustrating, no matter what difficulty setting you are playing on. This forces the player to redo a part of the game again in order to face the same boss (or bosses). Each repetition is about five minutes or longer, which constitutes of a problem to me, as dying with certain bosses occurs often. It is a game that may not be for everyone if the genre is not to their liking, but overall, it is quite the accomplishment, especially if you keep in mind that it was designed entirely by one single person, and achieves such positive results. The music is nothing short of superb. It embodies all that was great from the 8-bit and 16-bit eras and makes it exceptional and complementing to the game's presentation and plot. There is also a considerable amount of replay ability, as there are unlockable game modes and four different endings. If you love platform games with shooter elements, this is a must play. If you are unsure about the genre, you owe it to yourself to give this indie classic a try.\n\nCave Story+ is great.

reviewText:
3 difficulties, 3 different endings, easter eggs, secret weapons, sidequests... you'll play this game more than once to unlock it all; but it's very addicting so you'll enjoy each time. And after clear it, you still have new modes to try.
They are all good things in this amazing game: Retro style, a good story, several weapons (each one very different than the others), cute characters, exciting Megaman-like fast-paced gameplay combined with some RPG... return to the golden era of 16bits!
In fact, a single person made this game [!]

Oh, if you played the original freeware version of this game, don't worry; there's a lot of new content. And if you don't like the new graphics/music, you can choose to play with the original ones. What game let you do that?

reviewText:
It's Cave Story- play it.

EDIT:  Some people have not heard about this still, I suppose, so... it is a one man project from 2005 that inspired the makers of Super Meat Boy and is credited with a rise in indie developers trying to accomplish larger tasks outside of their niche group.  After it's freeware release it was remade to all late 21st century Nintendo consoles, and fans made it portable to the original Xbox and some graphing calculators (along with Mac and Linux).

After all these years critics have called it the King of the Indies"
date: commending it for its masterful game design and storytelling.\n\nEven if you do not like semi-open/branching world story-driven 2D sidecrolling shoot'em-ups
recommended: then this game is worth a purchase
hoursPlayed: because being a PC gamer in this golden age of indie development and not looking into Cave Story means missing out on how our culture has developed
voteText: and what values started it all.  It is the same thing as being a huge fan of Naruto and One Piece but never taking a look at Dragon-Ball (even if the show REALLY repels you)
helpfulPercent: or reading great modern fantasy like Game of Thrones or Tad Williams without reading The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings.\n\nChances are you will love it anyway."

reviewText:
The art is lovely in this game, and the game plays pretty good as well. The controls are a bit twitchy though (playing with a controller) so that could use some work, and I absolutely hate the savepoints. Yes, I get it. You're supposed to be careful (or the game is supposed to be hard). But how can you be careful when even the environments can kill you ? It's a poor design choice if you ask me. But it's definitely one to way to extend game time.
But other than that, it's a brilliant old school action platformer with a level up (and level down if you get hit too often) system... and (mini-)bosses ! Everyone loves boss battles, right ? I do, I do !
So ignore the save system and you've got a great game in your hands.

[Rating: 76/100]

This game has a wonderful story with multiple endings, great art style and soundtrack. Imagine Mario + undertale with guns. Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who is alive, but sadly I can't recommend this game on steam because you can get it for free and legally(hopefully) from a fan website, just google cave story. But cave story+ does allow for remastered graphics and sound. but the price is a bit much for not much extra i would still recoment downloading it from the fan website and if you really like it, buy it here...... (p.s. im only 14 and not exactly a master critique, so judge accordingly)

reviewText:
55/10
One of the best Indie games. If not THE best.
It's a great mix of Metroid, Castlevania and (a little bit of) Zelda.
The story, the characters, the combat system, the music, everything is just awesome.
And to top it all, certain decisions grant other items or lead to different endings which provides a high replay value.
Warning: Extremely addictive. I've finished it 6 times and it still isn't boring.

Great extra: You can choose if you want to play the game in the original art style (as Pixel, the creator of the original game, made it) or in an enhanced style with smoother, hand-drawn-like graphics.
The same goes for the soundtrack (original chiptune-like, remastered and new).

reviewText:
I do recommend this one.
The game start you really helpless, but soon you get your first weapon.
Addictive. In one word, that's what it is.
Pixel art is great and polished,
music scores are incredible,
scenario flow like master storytellers directed it,
the game creates a lot of great emotions,
it has surprisingly epic moments of sentimental creesentos,
i have no words!
This game is an outstanding experience,
old svhool platform lovers will love it,
new age gamers will appreciate elements other than graphics and gameplay, that are really forgotten and undermined nowadays in most of the releases.

Gameplay is great, it gets enhanced with new features as it goes on, arrow keys, z,x,s,q are the keys you will need, easy peasy to get used to it.

Difficulty is great measured. Not so easy not so hard.

Add one more feature! You make choices. From minor to major, this keeps replayability at high rates.

Cave Story + is an excelleng game in all aspects.

reviewText:
I played the freeware version way back when and this is basically that +1. The new sprites look really smooth and the addition of several save files and some different modes increase the already initially large amount of replayability. I stil prefer the classic music, however.

As for the game itself, it's a Metroid/Castlevania style of game where you collect power ups and weapons in an open style of world. It also has quite an interesting plot if you get into it.

Tl;dr if you don't want to buy what I consider to be the greatest indie game ever, at least google up the old freeware version and play that. This is not a game to miss out on.

reviewText:
This game is one of the best adventure games I have ever played!
It's an old game in retro style, which just got updated with High Definition graphic, that's why it's called 'Cave Story+'. (The original Cave Story isn't available on Steam btw)
Cave Story is a great 2D game, where you play a robot named 'Quote', who just lost his memories and gets to know what happened the farther you play the game.
So, where to start?
First off, the Story is quite nice... not the best but it's nice. I don't want to spoil to much but as mentioned, you wake up somewhere and you don't know how you landed there nor what your past is. You have to fight your way through the levels to find out who you are and what you actually did. To reach your goal you'll have to use many different weapons... There's a big arsenal of weapons, but not all of these are obtainable in one single playthrough. The different enemies differ from each other so there's always another strategy how to beat them, the same applies to bosses. The levels are awesome made and the retro graphic style makes this game in it's look beautiful.

And if this game was too easy for you, there are a lot of items you can collect and many challenges to complete. In case you aim for all achievements, you'll have to beat this game multiple times because - as mentioned before - you can't get all items in one single playthrough.

Anyone who has never played it yet, has something missed in his life. This game is just awesome!
You won't regret your buy and you'll love this game!
In my opinion maybe the BEST adventure game, which was ever made! :D
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Interesting and nice game. However grab yourself a walkthrough if you want 100% completion, otherwise you might miss some story worthy stuff. Now probably the answer to the biggest question, is it worth paying for the new stuff? Well, if you find it on a decent sale why not? The visual and audio upgrade are sweet enough and the a new level sure make it a bit longer.

Don't get this on full price if you never played the original FREE ONE.
Don't rush into buying it if you never played or at least checked the FREE ONE.

reviewText: Great indie game about exploring a large underground world and picking up items that allow you to continue progressing, sort of like Metroid before it went 3D and terrible (exception: Prime 1). Shoot monsters, jump platforms, rock out to the great sound track, and best the bosses. This is a remake of a cult classic, originally fan-translated from a Japanese PC game.\n\nI don't want to give away the plot, so I'll just say buy it if you're looking for a fun single player romp with cute graphics and good run and gun platforming action.

reviewText:
Recommended with some remarks.
Old School plataform game. Cute characters, simplist scenarios but, attracting, at the end.
Hard. You are dead really fast and, the saving spots are spread in each level so, you will repeat the same several times, which can be annoying and frustrating for most of people (including myself).
But, I don't know what, the game invites you to continue playing; it has some magic...

Only negative I can say is that the game should be automatically saved before starting to fight against any boss, otherwise you have to re-do the path to the boss and follow the bunch of dialogues before the fight, what can be really boring. Another thing that I hate is that every time you enter in any room, the complete scenario resets and the already killed enemies respawn.
It would be a perfect game if it allowed to save the progress at any time.
To repeat several times same thing is boring and kills the overall charming of the game.

reviewText: Cave Story is an indie adventure game in the tradition of Metroid, Kid Icarus and Simon's Quest. It combines classic pixel platforming with exploration, a large open world and an assortment of collectible weapons and upgrades. While it visually looks like a much more polished verison of a game from that age, Cave Story also includes some enhanced features like a storyline reminiscent of Japanese RPGs and an in-game map like later metroidvania" games.\nCave Story does not do much by way of innovating; it is very much
recommended: an adventure platformer. However it is a very good action platformer that appeals to my sense of nostalgia and fills the need quick action platformer type games. It is definitely worth some time if you are looking for a metroidvania game or get the itch to play Super Metroid or Symphony Of The Night but want a game you have not already played."

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my low play time. I've been a Cave Story enthusiast since before CS+ existed. I bought this game because I want money to go to Pixel, because he's a boss.

What is Cave Story?

Well, once upon a time a really smart guy looked at emerging computer technology and said, What if we use this to have fun?" For a while things were great
date: but then the dreaded 'Video Games Industry' came and took all the fun away
recommended: replacing it with things like 'features' and 'innovation' and blah blah blah. Everyone was sad.\n\nThen Pixel rode in on a white horse
hoursPlayed:
weilding a 20 string electric guitar and a legendary sword that shoots awesomeness and bacon. Our mighty hero dropped trou and took a fat dump on the stale industry's stupid hi-res face. Then he made the GREATEST GAME OF ALL TIME and gave it away for free. (You can get the original CS with bonus materials for free on the CS website.)

And the moral of the story is: NOW YOU CAN BE A HAPPY PERSON.

Cave Story recaptures the soul of classic NES and SNES era games. It does everything right that those games did
voteText: and then it does everything right that those games didn't. Every inch of the game radiates pure fun and excellent design
helpfulPercent: and you don't have to play long before you realize that this is something that someone made for the love of the game rather than to try and squeeze another nickel out of you with the latest lame gimmick.\n\nCave Story seems like a simple metroidvania platformer
votesHelpful: but don't be fooled. There are cool secrets hidden all over the place. The game just plays so smoothly that you don't even realize that you're making plot decisions and weapons selections as you go along.\n\nIf you like to have fun then go grab the Ultimate CS pack from the website and play the game. When you've finished crying ecstatic tears of reverent joy
votesTotal: you'll want to buy CS+. Not for the new bonus modes
votesFunny: not for the remastered graphics and music
commentsCount:
not even for the steam acheivements.

You'll want to buy CS+ out of sheer gratitude.

Now go forth! Be happy!"

reviewText:
hOI! =^_^= Well it's one of the most endearing thrillrides I've played through. Can't recall how many times I've played this and replayed it again and again, by now. Even though it's not 100% feature complete, if you don't want to spend money, play the free version! I did play through this on the Raspberry Pi via NXENGINE as well and it was just as much fun. It's still a very heartbreaking and heartwarming experience all throughout, much like Undertale has been. Some scenes aren't easy to take for me.

This game is special. I didn't have this on Steam yet, so ... (MRROW! *Pounce*), GOT IT! <3 <3 <3

Oh, it's a sweet and playful platformer-metroid-vania"-style sidescrolling shooter strong on secrets and story and characters. You better experiment and explore. And get a happy ending for everyone. Also .. those cheerful toasty melodic tracks are just amazing!

It's not an easy game
date: but you know you can do it! =^_^="

reviewText: A very enjoyable little retro game with a quite interesting story. You start as this person who has no memory of what happened and you soon find out you are on a floating island and a evil mad Doctor is plotting to take over the world and become ruler of all. You meet many interesting characters along the way as well as some memorable villains and there are different endings depending on how you play the game and what routes you take.\n\nA surprising amount of fun and controller use recommended for this title. Hell of a lot of fun and well worth the price :)

reviewText:
Cave Story is kinda supposed to be a modern classic metroidvania action platformer, but I can't really say that I found it any more than average in it's gameplay mechanics and design.  The action itself is ok, but somewhat repetitive however there are a couple mechanics that are REALLY annoying.  The weapon leveling sounds good at first but the ease with which you lose the weapon levels causes lots of trouble mid-battle, and more importantly wastes a ton of time with grinding, checkpointing and then getting going again;  which slows down the pacing considerably if you want your weapons fully leveled ... and you do, because the fights can be quite challenging.  A good deal of the challenge though comes just from the widely spaced checkpoints which are quite annoying, especially if you have to go back through the same grindy level bits and unskippable cut scenes to get back to a failed boss battle which is a shame because they would be very good battles if you weren't already in a bad mood from having to grind and cut scene your way back to them ...

So that's the bad side on the better side the sound track is EXCELLENT chip tune inspired work, probably the best element of the game, and there are a lot of tracks which are well placed and distributed.  I suppose the story itself is pretty interesting and unique but leaves quite a bit unanswered, which is fine.

Conclusion: I'm not sorry that I played Cave Story+, but the amount of time that it wastes in between the good bits is sufficient to keep me from recommending it.

reviewText:
Ahh, Cave Story, everyone loves it, it made a big splash on the indie game scene and pretty well changed the industry!

...but I don't like it.
It's far from the worst game but it has a fair share of problems that add up to a rather unpleasant experience for me overall.

First and foremost, the platforming controls. They're very floaty and slippery. I seriously though the game was running slow when I first started playing it. And then you combine this with the fact that a lot of platforming in this game involves one-tile blocks and... well, you can fall off pretty easily. It feels like you fall off edges the moment any part of your sprite leaves a ledge, too, I fairly often fell off a ledge because I jumped just a little too late in what would otherwise be a normal jump time in any other platformer. I will say that the weapons are pretty satisfying and varied, they all feel like they have a purpose. Well, most of them at least. And they're pretty fast and/or powerful, too. I like the semi-boost that the machine gun can give you, but it's too bad getting that weapon prevents you from getting a much better one down the line.

The other huge problem I have in this game is the level design and story progression. Not the story itself, it's fine and fairly interesting with multiple endings and such, that's okay. But... alright. I understand that Pixel didn't have the means to make a massive game, but... retreading over the same patch of land in the Bushlands for the 6th time is just not fun at all. There are three main fetch quests that occur in the game, and all three of them are exercises in tedium. The Bushlands has you collect Jellyfish Juice no less than three times from the same spot near the beginning, and two of those times (or one if you know in advance) involves basically trekking all the way across the stage and back again. But even that is topped by good 'ol Sand Zone, which has the most incomprehensibly bad design I've ever seen. Halfway through the area, you're given a fetch quest to find five things. Okay. But you can only carry one at a time, and when you get it you have to go back to the point where you were given the quest. So the last stretch of level, you have to travel halfway across and back twice, and then all the way across twice as well (and once back). Add to that, this last stretch involves fall-and-start-over-a-section design, twice, where you'll lose a minute of your life going through basic platforming with no enemies 'cause you killed them all if you fall off the one-tile blocks. This zone is painfully tedious and not even fun the first time through. The third major fetch quest happens at the Plantation, though it's thankfully not AS bad as the other two; gotta go a bit of a ways to get one item, exchange it for another, bring it back to the quest NPC, go get another item, bring it back, done, not as painful as the other two but at that point my patience was already wearing thin.

There's also two segments of the game (three if you go for the true ending) that feature everyone's favorite, checkpoint starvation! Revisiting the Egg Corridor and the boss rush at the end of the game, specifically, the former of which features a lot of instadeath traps and a surprise boss if you open a chest, with no save point until after the boss, and the latter which involves three relatively easy bosses followed by an incredibly spammy one with only the chance for a MINOR heal after the third, and dying at any point sends you back to the start to refight the other three bosses again. I understand that the end of the game should be harder than the rest, that's fine, but this is just plain cheap. The problem with these kind of things is that the rest of the game doesn't follow in their trends, save points are common and the emphasis is on shorter bursts of challenge. So putting these kind of sections in your game destroys any sense of a difficulty curve (and indeed, everything between these two points is relatively tame by comparison). The true ending level is even worse, featuring a longish level followed by 5 bosses with only a luck-based healing chance between the first and the other four. Marathon level it may be, fun it certainly is not, and not helping matters is that one room of the level is entirely luck based and most of the challenge from the level design comes from the enemy spam involved. It's really unpleasant to play through. The only remotely decent part of the level is the platforming bit at the start, but it's short and not really that great, the Hidden Last Cave had a lot more interesting platforming going on.

The tedium of the game is also increased by its nudging to replay the game and get the true ending. You won't get it the first time because doing so involves 1. making a difficult jump (unless you got the machine gun) and defying common sense by not talking to an injured NPC and 2. going through a long, rather non-obvious quest to revive a character that can be permanently screwed up in a number of ways very easily. And even then, you have to go into a building as the sky is literally falling at the end, just to gain access to the true ending. It's pretty hard to even know about without a guide, and honestly isn't worth the effort in the end. But anyways. Yes, replaying the entire game. You can't skip cutscenes, and the way the game is designed, you can't sequence break, you can't do anything to speed up the pace of the game other than be slightly better at it than the first time. And little else changes besides maybe having different weapons at different points or not having the booster for a boss. Playing this game once was already tedious enough, even replaying on easy and having everything be a breeze to get through doesn't reduce the tedium of a second or third playthrough.

Minor gripes, but the presentation of the game isn't great either. Yeah the original graphics were made by one guy but this is the remastered version, you can do a bit more than just make everything look a tiiiiny bit better. The game's worlds look very bland and most backgrounds are just cave walls. The music's okay, nothing special.

Really, overall, I just... can't find a lot to like here. There's some decent bosses and a bit of decent platforming, fun weapons, an alright story... and I can respect that one guy made all this (originally, at least). Maybe it just hasn't held up well, you had to be there or something, but I don't believe that and I don't believe this is a very good game. Maybe it's just me, but. I do not like Cave Story.
voteText: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love Cave Story. In fact, I bought this simply to show support for Pixel, who is amazing; the amount of time and effort that went into the original is actually rather inspiring for a one man project. That said, what I paid money for was the original content, not what came with +.

I hate the new graphics and music, they're ugly to both senses. The translation, the most subjective part, to me is inferior to the original fan translation way back when. The only positive I can claim is that Curly Mode is a cute little different take on the whole game, but it's not something that can carry such a large price tag.

If you love the original Cave Story and want to toss some money at Pixel, then hey, buy it like me. If you've never played Cave Story, do so with the original freeware version, because there is nothing really here for any first time players.
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
EDIT/UPDATE: It has very recently come to my attention that Nicalis has decided to raise the price of the game from $9.99 to $14.99. In addition to this, it seems that Nicalis has also decided to not put the game on anymore sales, and from what I have heard, there hasn't been anything done to the game content-wise that could justify this. In other words, Nicalis has decided to raise the price just to gain more money. I can no longer see any reason to purchase this version of Cave Story, as I mentioned in my original review (which will still be posted below this paragraph) that there isn't enough content to justify a full price purchase of this particular version. Instead of purchasing this version of the game, I advise that you just go and download the freeware version of the game, as you will be saving a whole lot of money just downloading the freeware version than by buying an overpriced version of a game that, while good, isn't worth $14.00. $9.99 was already steep, but increasing the price without even adding any content to justify it is pathetic. Don't give Nicalis your money.


ORIGINAL POST: Despite starting one of the worst trends in gaming (indie gaming, to be more exact), Cave Story is actually a pretty damn good game made by just a single person. Of course, with that being said, I suggest that you play the original freeware version of the game first before using your money to buy Cave Story +, as this particular version of the game isn't much different from the original freeware game, save for some bonus content and some minor improvements. If you do decide that you want to purchase this version of the game, do wait a little to see if it goes on sale, as I don't think that there is enough content to justify a full-price purchase of this version of the game.

reviewText: I really enjoyed playing this game. From the beautiful pixel art and the 16-bit music, to the Metroidvania style, and the lovely characters. There are lots of moments that make you love the characters. Bad things appeared very soon into the game, as I got a map, but didn't know how to use it. Controls aren't well explained; I had to look for them in a website.\nThere's a high amount of achievements that make the game longer, experience points, levels, powers, lots of items, cool boss fights and other things that are common in Metroidvanias.\nSo, my conclusion is: this game is awesome. It was in the last Humble Bundle, so there are lots of people who have it but haven't tried it yet (like me some hours ago). Give it a try; you've got nothing to lose.

reviewText:
This game is just awesome.

Cave Story+ is a great game, it has decent gameplay, and the graphics aren't too shabby either.  (Although it is not very common to find a game in a more pixelated style these days.)  One thing I like about the control scheme is that you can, well, modify which button corresponds to which control in the game.  As expected, the controls in-game are responsive, like movement and shooting.  Additionally, the game gives off a very retro style due to its pixel style.  (You can even set the
graphics to Original" for an even more retro experience
date: although I'd recommend "New" because they look more refined.)\n\nThere is one downside to this game
recommended: though.  This game only has a Story Mode and Curly Story mode with three saves each
hoursPlayed: and a few special challenge levels.  There isn't much else to do in the game
voteText: however the difficulty modes and options to trade weapons within the game (aquiring special weapons from NPCs
helpfulPercent: there is no actual trading in the Cave Story games) do add some replay value.  There are three endings in total
votesHelpful: and if you're trying to get a specific ending (I won't tell which one) you'll have to go through a secret stage after the "canon" events of the game.  The secret level has a surprise at the end..  You'll have to find out yourself if you want to know what it is.\n\nI initially was not knowledgeable that you could shoot upwards and downwards
votesTotal: and so I only shot left and right.  When I actually figured out about the full firing capabilities
votesFunny: I face-palmed and said to myself
commentsCount: "This isn't Megaman
column16: I can shoot up and down!" (So you can shoot upwards and downwards
column17: now you know.)\n\nIf you buy this game on Steam or the other ports on 3DS and Wii
column18: or even if you download the original version from the Internet
column19: hopefully this review will be useful to you.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText: A fun little indie game. Does it invoke classic Metroid"? No. Is it as good as Metroid? No. The only thing it has in common with Metroid is the sound when you grab a health powerup. But for what it is
date: it is done very well. Indeed the NES could have used more games like this rather than having roughly 90% of its games be complete garbage that I found out through many wasted weekends renting ♥♥♥♥ing trash games when I was younger. This game has great retro graphics and good sound and music
hoursPlayed: and solid level design. Retro platformers should always be welcome to any gamer with a brain.\nThe only thing that killed this game dead in the water for me was the last battle. You have to fight 4 bosses with 1 life bar and a life full up jar
voteText: and it's not that it is hard that gets me
helpfulPercent: just pure frustration at it's worst. Trust me
votesHelpful: beat the first 3 bosses with 1 life bar then use the jar for the final battle. That is your only hope. If you die
votesTotal: you have to do it all over again and go through all the dialogue. It will test even the most dedicated persons patience. There are no words to describe the frustration it causes. Don't get me wrong
votesFunny: I beat it after many tries
commentsCount: but the infinite frustration level still remained. Besides the last battles completely ruining it for me
column16: I liked it."

reviewText:
Is this the real life?
Is this just fantasy?
Caught in a landslide,
No escape from reality.

Open your eyes,
Look up to the skies and see,
I'm just a poor boy, I need no sympathy,
Because I'm easy come, easy go,
Little high, little low,
Anyway the wind blows doesn't really matter to me, to me.

Mama, just killed a man,
Put a gun against his head,
Pulled my trigger, now he's dead.
Mama, life had just begun,
But now I've gone and thrown it all away.

Mama, ooh,
Didn't mean to make you cry,
If I'm not back again this time tomorrow,
Carry on, carry on as if nothing really matters.

Too late, my time has come,
Sent shivers down my spine,
Body's aching all the time.
Goodbye, everybody, I've got to go,
Gotta leave you all behind and face the truth.

Mama, ooh (anyway the wind blows),
I don't wanna die,
I sometimes wish I'd never been born at all.

I see a little silhouetto of a man,
Scaramouche, Scaramouche, will you do the Fandango?
Thunderbolt and lightning,
Very, very frightening me.
(Galileo) Galileo.
(Galileo) Galileo,
Galileo Figaro
Magnifico.

I'm just a poor boy, nobody loves me.
He's just a poor boy from a poor family,
Spare him his life from this monstrosity.

Easy come, easy go, will you let me go?
Bismillah! No, we will not let you go. (Let him go!)
Bismillah! We will not let you go. (Let him go!)
Bismillah! We will not let you go. (Let me go!)
Will not let you go. (Let me go!)
Never, never let you go
Never let me go, oh.
No, no, no, no, no, no, no.
Oh, mama mia, mama mia (Mama mia, let me go.)
Beelzebub has a devil put aside for me, for me, for me.

So you think you can stone me and spit in my eye?
So you think you can love me and leave me to die?
Oh, baby, can't do this to me, baby,
Just gotta get out, just gotta get right outta here.

(Oh, yeah, oh yeah)

Nothing really matters,
Anyone can see,
Nothing really matters,
Nothing really matters to me.

Anyway the wind blows.

reviewText:
This is possibly one of the best story game I've played, if not the best. Even if you have seen a playthrough of it, you should still get it as the experience on it's own is a major success. The story is compelling and the secrets in the game are worth spending time in finding, as well as the soundtrack being fully atmospheric and powerful. The different story paths make the game playable in more than just doing one playthrough as there's many different options and choices.

Only problem is that it's going to be a while before another game like this comes out!

10/10 Definitely worth the price tag.

reviewText: When I say I don't recommend Cave Story+, what I really mean is, I recommend the original (and free) Cave Story instead.\n\nIt's not that Cave Story+ is bad, really. There's some interesting extra stuff to try out. It's just really not worth paying for it. Updated graphics and music is nice, but the originals were fine and undeniably had a certain charm to them. The new English translation, while in some regards technically better, lacks many of the quirks that Aeon Genesis' original translation made beloved by English-speaking fans (huzzah!"). And things like difficulty modes are essentially redundant
date: since there already exist established challenges that simulate harder difficulties.\n\nWhat would really have made for a nice Cave Story+ would be the inclusion of more flexible tools
voteText: would've been well worth the money."

reviewText:
Cave Story is lauded by many players and reviewers as a grand masterpiece of an indie game. I disagree, I think it's popularity as a novel, well constructed freeware experience inflated the reputation of this little game to the point that years later it simply doesn't hold up to the hype.

Before diving in, I'll make the simple statement that $15 is severly overpriced for 3-4 hours of a sub-par experience.

The story was perhaps what dissapointed me most. The story for this game is said by some (including its own store page) to be rich and original. Unfortunately, this just isn't the case. The story is an extremely straight forward mad scientist trying to take over the world" narrative
date: with the miguided (if persistent) drive to constantly be extremely cute that a lot of Japanese media today shares. Some of the characters seem interesting
recommended: but an overall lack of meaningful characterisation makes them more like simple cartoon characters the player can immediately understand rather than authenitc people and animals. The closest game narrative to Cave Story's that I can think of is Sonic the Hedgehog 2
hoursPlayed: and that's a pretty low bar.\n\nWhile maybe I can excuse what I view to be an extremely typical
voteText: lackluster story
helpfulPercent: I can't forgive the dissapointing gameplay. Any allusions to the Metriodvania genre when reffering to Cave Story are misleading at best. The game does not permit
votesHelpful: require
votesTotal: or encourage exploration or mystery in a major way
votesFunny: let alone use it as a core engagment. The fairly fast paced action-platforming does provide some challenge
commentsCount: but it doesn't hold up over time.\n\nThe jumping and shooting simply doesn't create a large number of interesting challenges or situations during the game. After the first hour the mechanics of the game have basically played themselves out
column16: and nothing experientially different really comes out of the gameplay
column17: largely due to the repetitive design of enemy encounters. The weapon leveling system is novel and seems like a good idea; for the first hour or so I played very deliberately so I could get my weapons to maximum power and keep them there. However
column18: this quickly becomes old hat and the interesting idea of this system just becomes tedious when the game gets tougher
column19: and taking a single hit can force you to switch from attacking to recovering lost power ups over and over again.\n\nI was dissapointed by Cave Story
column20: but I would still recommend people to try it out. The original version is available for download on the internet for free
column21: and at that price it's worth it to play through and form your own opinions. If nothing else
column22: the free version of Cave Story is worth playing in order to see a piece of foundational indie-gaming history.\n\nTL
column23: DR: Doesn't live up to the hype
column24: uninspired story and unengaging gameplay. Not worth $15 but the free version is online so I recommend trying it for yourself."

reviewText:
This game is hugely popular, but I was disappointed. Maybe you'll like it, though, and I hope my review can help you decide.

My biggest issue was that it's often called a Metroidvania, but the first 80% of the game was missing any exploration: the gameplay is very linear, even if you're doing some backtracking. The bosses and minibosses are a bit repetitive. There's very little in the way of puzzle bosses or even puzzles in general, unless you count talking to everyone until you find the right dialogue trigger.

Thematically it's a bit of a mess: a hodgepodge of sci-fi and fantasy. (These two genres certainly can be combined well, but it needs to be done coherently.) The story is not that epic or original, and the dialogue could use some serious editing. The description calls the game massive"
date: and that's a definite exaggeration.\n\nThe action gameplay itself is pretty good. The controls felt a bit floaty to begin with
recommended: but this gets much better when you gain the ability to hover. The leveling system for weapons is a nice touch. There's a good variety of weapons
hoursPlayed: but 95% of the time I just went with the machine gun.\n\nSo if you want an action platforming game with charming retro graphics
voteText: cute soundtrack
helpfulPercent: and straightforward gameplay that you can finish in a few hours
votesHelpful: this could easily be the game for you. If you've heard it's a massive Metroidvania or that the story is amazing
votesTotal: I would temper my expectations."

reviewText:
This is a first impressions review as my playtime shows.

Cavestory poorly starts players off in a setting where they dont know what they are doing. This goes for controls, plot and the fact that you cant attack right off when you have enemies in front of you implying that ther'es some way to defeat them.
The music is well done and has many variations (original, remastered and new) but, i felt it was a little generic if not cookie cut, same goes for the graphics.
Controls for the game i felt were akward and clunky, the keys were not even rebindable.
The story (as little as i got) thus far was uninvolving as if the character didnt have any connection to anything around him at all.
The difficulty isn't what makes you die in this game, it's the fact that you have to die, memorize certain traps or suprise enemy locations and redo it, very frustrating.

I never want this to be the kind of standard for any indie developer, ever, sorry.

3 out of 10 peashooters

reviewText: Cave Story’s basic side-scrolling shoot-em-up gameplay is well worn, and the few noteworthy changes made to that genre’s basic formula don’t make for interesting or marked improvements. Additionally, progress through its mostly linear narrative is heavily gated by unmarked objectives, frequently requiring an unwarranted and unrewarding amount of backtracking and trial-and-error.
