reviewText:
This is not a good PC port...of a free game that's already on PC.

The original game, a grand freeware game by Pixel, was light, functional and compatible. This, one of many ports responsible mainly by Nicalis, is none of those.

Faulty gamepad support, crash prone, lack of resolution options (including any widescreen support, which the Wii version was able to [poorly] do), tacked on extra modes (the difficulty modes are self-imposable), and the, so-bland-it's-meh
date:
soundtracks and script of the oher rehash ports.

On the plus side, this is Cave Story: a wonderful action platformer. On the case for this specific version, at least the graphics are decent and it does include a cut area, but, ultimately, it's not worth spending money over.

This all happened in a manner of minutes. A terrible job on behalf of Nicalis.

Stick with the original version (it's FREE, nothing to lose), or, if you really wanted to buy Cave Story, the 3DS version would be the only one I'd reccomend purchasing (all features from CS+, portability, optional 3D, supports proper 16:9, stable, $10). If you want to support Pixel (you should), go buy 10 copies of Azarashi instead.
helpfulPercent: 7 of 26 people (27%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Everything that made the freeware publish of this game what it was is not improved or expaned upon in this Steam port. You can argue and debate about how you can toggle off the extra things like the (awful) remixed music but that's avoiding the point. The point is that the very worthwhile experience of this game is available for free and this port does nothing to expand upon the (rather high) benchmark that it's predecessor set.\n\nA quick google search will show you how you can install the freeware publish of this game and a english patch (if needed). I would strongly recommend doing that, it is a very well-made gem of a game.

reviewText:
listen, before you let your fanboyism lash out at me, just listen.

this game is a love letter to difficult games yes, but objectively it clings to video game tropes that really need to die. I really don't mind difficulty in a game, if you even briefly browse my profile you can see that, however there is a major difference between fun difficulty and frustrating difficulty. let me explain in detail...

i really don't appreciate seperate endings that depend on arbatrary actions, IE having to make a jump that most would deem impossible with permenant reprocautions.

i really don't appreciate being given choices that downgrade my character for 40% of the game with absolutely no idea before-hand IE being given the choice of choosing a different gun with no option of going back.

I really don't appreciate having to replay huge sections of the game, because the creator refuses to put an extra checkpoint in because he insists on clinging to archaic game design. ghosts and goblins may be your childhood, but let's face the facts, that game would not have suffered, nor your experience, if it had the option to save.

but lastly, i really don't appreciate jumping through many arbitrary loops, so that i can get a non-♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending, only to come to a nigh-impossible set of obstacles and 4 bosses. listen, i know you think you feel much more satisfied knowing you beat hell, and 4 bosses, but I challenge you to think about something... would your experience REALLY have suffered if there was a checkpoint after hell? or after the first boss? or the second? or the third? would you really have thrown down the controller and been AHH ♥♥♥♥! AND I WAS HAVING SO MUCH FUN BEING CHALLENGED"

i really doubt it. but for those of us who memorized patterns for hell
date: and for the three of the four bosses
voteText: its assinine and it. is. not. fun.\n\ni would love to reccomend this game for the first half

votesTotal: only to be let down by a sub-par ending

reviewText: It's Cave Story with updated graphics and sound. It has translation errors, but that doesn't detract much from the story that you probably already know. To the uninitiated, cave story is a sidescrolling, high difficulty shooter with a whimsical style that makes it hard to get mad at the game for filling you up with bullets. It has a bit of replay value with three endings that, for the most part, are determined through the second half of the game.\n\nDying would be punishing by today's standards, with no lives system and only the ability to reload. It's a small thing to overlook considering how spoiled we are by quick loads.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Very fun adventure / platformer in the same vein as Metroid. Advance your weapons and stats as you go through the story, and there are plenty of hidden powerups and bonuses along the way.

Definitely worth at least two playthroughs of the story to see everything there is to offer. The game is also decently challenging - actually pretty tough in some parts - without being unfair, and the storyline has some very well written characters.

Besides a few minor nitpicks (one boss character in particular is re-used a lot, and so it's just tedious by the end), this is arguably the best indie" game on the market.

10/10 would buy"
